editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it is Acted at the NEW THEATRE IN Little Lincoln's-Inn-Fields BY His Majeſty's Servants.
Written by Mr. THO. DOGGET, Comedian.
LONDON, Printed for Sam. Briſcoe at the Corner of Charles-ſtreet, in Ruſſel-ſtreet, Covent-Garden; Sold by R. Wellington, at the Lute in St. Paul's Church-yard; R. Parker at the Royal-Exchange. 1696.

☞There is in the Preſs and will be ſpeedily Publiſh'd, Mr. Dennis's Miſcellany of Poems, with ſeveral Select Tranſlations from the Ancient Poets: Alſo, The Paſſion of Bibblis, Tranſlated into Engliſh, By Mr. Dennis.
〈…〉

div.head: TO THE Illuſtrious and Truly Noble Prince JAMES, Duke, Marqueſs, and Earl of Ormond in England and Ireland; Earl of Oſſory, and Viſcount Thurles; Baron of Arclo; Lord of the Regalities and Liberties of the County of Tiperary; Baron of Lanthony; Earl of Brecknock; Chancellor of the Ʋniverſity of Oxford, One of the Lords of the Bed-Chamber to His Sacred Majeſty, Knight of the moſt Noble Order of the Garter; and One of His Majeſty's moſt Honourable Privy Council.
div.p:
I Know what I ought to expect from this Preſumption, but the aſſurance I had of your Graces Goodneſs to forgive me, made me ſuffer my Inclinations to get the better of me, and beſeech your Protection for this poor Play, that has but little elſe to recommend it to the World, the ſatisfaction I had to ſee the little Succeſs it undeſervedly met with from the Town, gave me not ſo great pleaſure as I
have to ſee your Graces Name fix'd to the Dedication; not that I Pride my Self upon any imaginary Deſert; but the occaſion it gives me of doing the Duty of an Engliſhman, from whom all that's due to the Preſerver of his Country, ſhou'd be paid to your Grace; this, I confeſs, ought to be my Task, I own my Obligation, tho' I cannot pay it, nor am I much concern'd at it, ſince a better Pen than mine will find it a Duty too difficult to be Juſt in; and the generality of Mankind, I'm ſure, will think me in the right, not to prophane your Noble Character, by endeavouring to deſcribe it, which wou'd betray my Ignorance, more than the Publiſhing this piece of Folly will do, which coſt me more Time (and Trouble) to get Acted, than did to Write it except one Act of it, which I wrote three Years ago,) As for its Faults, one of them is, I hear, that it is Obſcene, I'm ſorry it ſhou'd appear ſo, I'm ſure I never deſign'd it, and I believe it will
be hard to find a Comedy with leſs in it; thoſe that have the cleareſt Reputation, have more Reaſon to bluſh for that Sin, than this has; I own there's a ſcarcity of that which ſome call Wit, and what many Authors in this Age run mad after, endeavouring to produce it out of every bodys Mouth, whether it belongs to their Character or no, ſtill loſing the Man to goe out of the way for a Jeſt; 'tis what I ſhall never labour for, (either in Writing, if I were capable, or Acting;) for he that will make Nature his Study, will find more Charms in it, and a more certain way to Applauſe, than can be produc'd from any abortive Conceit, which at beſt, can but repay him with a loud Laughter from the Multitude, who ſhou'd be pleas'd, I own, but not at the expence of the Author, or the Actors Reputation, nor the Diſpleaſure of the Judicious, who I hope will not condemn this Play from the appearance it had upon the Stage, where it ſuffer'd
in the Acting. By the Induſtrious Care of whom, was ſo viſible to the Audience, I ſhall ſpare any further Reflexion at this time, which could chiefly be ſpent in begging your Grace's Pardon, for preſuming ſo unworthily to write my ſelf,

closer.signed: Your Grace's moſt Humble, Faithful and Obedient Servant, THO. DOGGET.

div.head: PROLOGUE
Spoken by Mrs. BARRY.
div.l: NEW Plays as well as Guineas fall of late,
Like Addle Plotters hurried to their Fate,
And yet our Ben wou'd needs be Plotting too,
But only Plotted for himſelf and you;
But yet I fear he will not pleaſe to day,
Alas! 'tis a meer out-of-faſhion Play;
No Bawdy in't to make the Ladies Glow,
Nay, what is worſe, the Play's without a Beau;
No Chit-Chat Repartee, nor Raillery,
Such as Masks ſell Sins within the Gallery;
Stuff learnt by Rote, paſs with you for Sence,
Brought here by Wits, and by Fools carry'd hence,
Nay, he has to day, ſpar'd min' honeſt Citt,
Who's Holiday Halfe Crown ſeats him i'th' Pit,
And Laughs when he's abus'd, becauſe 'tis Wit;
Thus all he doe's but Politickly ſpare,
He fears to Bite, yet hardly can forbear,
The Poet wou'd be at you, if he might,
Did not the Player deter him from the Fight;
He Draws on your ſide, Swears you ſhall not frown,
The Comick Vein ſhall keep the Cynick down,
'Twixt you and him no Quarrel yet has been
If now he eres, he'll freely own his Sin;
Nay, what's more ſtrange, he will repent on't too,
But not as other wretched Scriblers do:
Attempt to mend, yet trouble ſtill the Age,
Confirm them Blockheads, and Confound the Stage.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
Spoken by Mr. Betterton.
div.l: THE Careful Pilot, when he Views the Shelf
Where others have been loſt, ſecures himſelf;
The Cautious Robber from that road abſtains,
Where his unlucky Comrade hangs in Chains;
Thus all, except the Brothers of the Quill,
Take Early Warning by another's ill.
Writing's the Fatal Rock, on which has ſplit
Many a Stout, and well-built Man of Wit;
And yet there's not a Sculler but ſhall Dare
To venture his weak, rotten Cock-boat there,
Bleſs me! What Wits might ſome Men be to th'Sight;
Wou'd they be rul'd, and neither Talk, nor Write;
For here's the Miſchief of the Poet's trade;
He muſt be born a Wit, as well as made;
A Native, inbred ſpark of Heavenly heat,
In ev'ry Vein, in ev'ry Pulſe muſt beat:
Nor will indifferent Writing do the feat,
For Poetry allows no Middle State.
No ſo-ſo Plays will do, no pretty-well,
You fail if you but Moderately excell;
It muſt be Heaven all, or elſe 'tis Hell.
Criticks are Heralds, that deny one blot
To be of Honour in a Poet's Coat:
'Tis time and labour thrown away in all,
But they that do perceive an inward Call;
And by the Orthodox none ought to be
Admitted to this Sacred Miniſtry,
Leſs then a Dryden, Congreve, Wycherly.
Theſe Matters running in our Author's head,
He vows to me have almoſt made him Mad;
To know ſo well the Strictneſs of the Rule,
And yet to write; Incorrigible Fool!
Yonder he ſtands in Sad and Doloful Caſe,
Waiting the Judgment you ſhall pleaſe to paſs;
I ſee he beckons to me, to intreat
That you'd be Merciful as you are Great:
Almighty Criticks, you his Judges ſit;
If you conſent he ſhall ſet up a Wit,
He ſwears he wont be prouder for't a Bit.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: SIR, Here's a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Letter, Let me ſee it.

body.p: I arriv'd this Day at London, and to Morrow, purpoſe for Glouceſter: where, if after Three Years Travel, I can find my Friend what I left him; I cannot think my Self Ʋnhappy, how unfortunate ſoever I may ſeem to the World.

sp.p:
I wiſh Ned, it were in my Power to make thee as happy, as it was in thy Father's to make thee miſerable; thou ſhould'ſt find a better Welcome here from thy Friend, then thou wilt from a Dead Sire, and departed Acres, Sirrah, go to Sir Thomas Teſties, and ſee if • e's
at home, and at leiſure to receive an Hours Converſation.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What Acknowledgments ſhall I make my Stars for letting me live to ſee once more, the Man that's neareſt to my Heart?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There let me grow; till want of Friendſhip makes me unworthy, of the Place—I was juſt now Reading your Letter, and by that, did not expect to ſee you theſe two Days; How came you ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I deſign'd to come in the Stage-Coach, but finding no other Company but an old talkative Woman, and two over-grown Boys, I choſe rather than be coop'd up with Old Age and Ignorance, to ride Poſt, and run the hazard of breaking my Neck upon Hackney Jades: that have, I think, disjointed every Limb of me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I wiſh Ned after the fatigue of thy Journey, I cou'd Entertain thee with ſomething wou'd divert thy preſent pain, and prove a Cordial for the future; for the News I have to tell thee, I fear will diſorder thy whole Frame, and make thy Mind as diſtemper'd as thy Body.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say'ſt thee ſo, prithee out with it at once; for I am Arm'd againſt the worſt that can befall me; my Life, which is the laſt and only thing Fate can now take from me; I ſee in no Danger, as for any other misfortune, there can come none ſo great as what is paſt.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I know not what you have met with abroad; but the greateſt you are to expect here, is the News of your Father's Death, who departed a Fortnight ſince; but before he left the World, took care to make you a younger Brother to his Extravagancy, which has left you ne'r a Groat, for he play'd the laſt Game with the laſt ſtake, and Died, leaving hardly enough to Bury him.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This I heard at London, and expected it long before: for when he ſent me abroad, it was only that I might not be a Curb to his Will, which was as unbounded as his Luſts, that t wou'd be obey'd in all thoſe Vices his younger Years ough to have been aſham'd of; but the Age we live in is ſo perverted, that Old Men purſue the Vanities of Youth (taking up the Cudgels they lay down) and fumble with thoſe Debauches, young Men grow weary of.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou ſay'ſt true, Ned; but I wiſh thou hadſt not experienc'd it ſo much at thy own Coſt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So do I Frank; but ſince it was in my Power to prevent it, it ſhall not now be my fault to repine at it; the Old Gentleman cou'd not 'a choſen a better time to put me to my Shifts, ſince the War gives me ſo Glorious an opportunity to try what Fortune has in ſtore for me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fortune! Prithee what canſt thou hope from Fortune, with Bullets flying about thy Ears, that cou'd Buffet thee ſo unmercifully in the time of Peace; Had'ſt thou a Friend indeed who had Intereſt to get thee a Commiſſion, that had Authority in it to keep thee out of Harms way, thou might'ſt hope as much as another Man; But as thou haſt nothing to prefer thee, but a comely Figure of Six Foot high, thou oughtſt to look for nothing more, then after the firſt Volley, to chance on a clean place to meaſure thy Length on, without ſpoiling thy Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee Frank, What Commands are thoſe that have Power to awe a Bullet, for till now, I never heard a Cannon made any diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: True Ned, if we come in their way; but I've known ſome Men, whoſe Actions were above being queſtion'd, ſtep aſide when Danger fac'd 'em, but if their Enemies (meeting with the worſt of it) have been forc'd to turn their Backs, have fall'n in like Lions, to ſcramble for Honour, and come home laden with as much as he that deſerv'd moſt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
I muſt confeſs we have too frequent Examples
of this kind; however it ſhall not keep me from doing my beſt to ſerve my Country, nor make medeſpair of Succeſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You do well to hope the beſt; it doubles our misfortunes to afflict our Selves with the Apprehenſion of 'em; which ſometimes make 'em look more dreadful than they are in themſelves.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That will never be my fault, for diſappointments are ſo frequent with me, that I ſhou'd look for nothing elſe, did I not believe all things muſt have an end, one time or other.
How now, Did not I ſend you to Sir Thomas Teſties?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I was going as you commanded me; and met his Man by the way, coming with a Meſſage to you, and he is now without, waiting to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This Old Knight (Ned) was a Citizen of London, but being weary of his Vocation, and willing to keep a young Wife to himſelf, is come to inhabit here, upon an Eſtate which he has lately purchas'd; part of it was your Fathers: he has one only Daughter by a former Wife, whom Nature has been very bountiful to, ſhe wants no Charm to make her Self Ador'd, and hath found that way to my Heart, which none of her Sex cou'd ever do before. There is a Neece (Ned) is equally deſerving, and would be equally deſirable, did not Love to ſhew his Power, byaſs my Affections: Come, thou ſhalt go with me and ſee them, if thy Journey has not fatigu'd thee too much.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Never to hinder me from the Company of a pretty Woman Frank; that Temptation is more prevalent with me than any other, Nature can be liable to: But at preſent I muſt deny my ſelf that ſatisfaction; I hear the Poſt goes hence within theſe Two Hours, and I have Buſineſs obliges me to write by the firſt opportunity; but let my Man go with you to acquaint my himſelf with the way; and I will come to you, as ſoon as I have diſpatch'd Jack, wait of Mr. Friendly, and come back quickly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: ▪Tis very well, Your Servant; Come back.

div.head: SCENE II. A Room at Sir T. Teſtie's.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Teſtie and Lucia.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Niece, come hither,—Come hither, I ſay, and ſhut the Door.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Bleſs us! What's amiſs in the State, that I muſt be Cloſeted.—The Door is lock'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very well; Come hither then:—Hark'ye, who am I?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay; whom am I?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are my Unkle, Sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Am I no more than your Unkle? your Father thought me worthy of a better Title, when he made me your Truſtee, and by that means impower'd me to make you a Beggar, had I not been your very good Friend as well.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, you have been more than I cou'd hope for—Nor ſhall you ever find me wanting in thoſe Acknowledgments your Goodneſs has oblig'd me to pay you, for your extraordinary Care of me, when I was left young and unable to take any for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; Why then, ſince occaſion now preſents, wherein you may in ſome meaſure requite my Love, and diſcharge your Duty, I expect you ſhall be ſincere with me, and Anſwer me directly;—When was Mr. Friendly laſt with my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I ſay, When was Mr. Friendly laſt with my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To the beſt of my Remembrance—Sir—I won't—be poſitive—but—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
But—No, no hold—hold—lookd'ye ſee, If I catch you ſtumbling, or endeavouring by your Female Devil's Wit at a pinch, to caſt a blind upon my
Underſtanding, I ſhall conclude you as bad as ſhe, and both alike ſhall ſhare • y Reſentment. Therefore come, I ſay, and Anſwer directly to the Queſtion, for I will know it, and from you Huſwife—You that are her Confident, as you call it,—Her Help-Mate to Iniquity: What, becauſe I am Old, and can't go withour a Staff, you think I'm Blind and can't See your Roguery without a pair of Spectacles,—but I have found you out Miſtreſs, I have ſo.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Found us out; I hope, Sir, you don't think that ſhe wou'd Act, or I Aſſiſt her, in any thing, that might blame her Conduct to Mr. Friendly, who you know to be a worthy Gentleman, and one, I'm ſure, I have heard you ſay, you had rather diſpoſe of her to, then any Gentleman in the Country; and if ſo, I don't know why I ſhould conceal their being together, ſince their deſigns are Honourable.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How—What—Deſigns, and Honourable—What—without my Knowledge—without firſt conſulting me—that am her Father—whoſe ſole Right it is to diſpoſe of her Perſon; and dares he, without my Leave, my Conſent to Authorize his Pretenſions, make Love to her, under my roof? Were he a Prince, and wou'd Endow her like a Queen, and ſhou'd but think of ſuch a thing, without my Licence; I wou'd Lock her up till the Green-Sickneſs had made her Eat her paſſage to him thro' the Wall, tell her ſo, d'ye hear—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed old Gentleman, you wou'd a found neither Locks nor Bolts cou'd have held her,—Had ſhe not been diſoblig'd by his making you acquainted with his Love, for ſhe is ſuch a Friend to Diſobedience, that ſhe thought your being privy to the matter, a ſufficient Reaſon to diſcard him her Favour, ſo that now I hope you may have a very Dutiful Child of her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Was not that my Father that parted from you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Was he in Humour?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, a very ill one, at the news of your proceedngs with Mr. Friendly; If you think you ſhall dye for Love Floria, you may prepare your ſelf a Halter, and ſwing to Elizium as ſoon as you pleaſe, for your Father hath forbid the Banes; had he been firſt acquainted with your Lovers Inclinations, you might have eaten a Sack-Poſſet after a Matrimonial Grace together, according to Cuſtom; But you are now to be Lock'd up, and feed upon Chaulk and Lime, he ſays, till you have eaten a Paſſage to your Spark thro the Wall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'm glad to find him ſo reſolv'd, I ſhall now diſpoſe of my ſelf to my own liking; for had he been enclin'd to the Match, I was reſolv'd never to • ee Friendly more, for affronting my Love, by ſeeking me at my Father's Hands, when that had aſſur'd me to him before.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, Wou'd you not have your Father have a Power in diſpoſing you where he likes beſt?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, if he cou'd Command my Love; But ſince that's decree'd by a higher Power, I muſt go with my Heart whether he will or no; nor ſhall he have any Vote where he has no right to give it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: An excellent Piece of Sophiſtry to incourage Diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may call it what you pleaſe. But in following the dictate of my Paſſion, I obey the Power that made it; and my Duty towards Heav'n is to be conſider'd before that to my Father I take it; I ſhall therefore Marry without his Leave or Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why without his Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: For the pleaſure of what thou call'ſt Diſobedience. Why thou forget'ſt ſure that I am a Woman as thou art; the Sex that firſt taught it to the World, wou'dſt have me degenerate?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
O, by no means, Madam; pray go on, have a care of being unjuſt to your Self; whatever you do; and for the better incouragement to proceed, Know, your Father
hath ſent this day to Mr. Friendly to forbid him the Houſe, or approach it at his peril.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I know it, and by the ſame Meſſenger, I bid him me et me to night at the Garden Door; I ſcorn the Old Gentleman ſhou'd have the ſtart of me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And pray what's the buſineſs of your meeting? To contrive how you may run away with him?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That's as he ſhall deſerve, if he's as fond of the Vagabond Trick as my ſelf, and will be contented to take me for my own ſake, without any other Conſideration▪

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You'll be contented to pack up your Awls; that is a clean Smock, with a Suit of Night Cloaths thruſt into a Band-box, and bid Good-buoy Daddy;—Well ſpeed thee well, ſince thou art reſolv'd upon a mad Trick, I think indeed, thou cou'dſt not have choſen an honeſter Fellow to play it with.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may call it a mad Trick, but any other had been a fooliſh one, witneſs my Mother-in-law, had ſhe been Govern'd by her own Will, my Father had wanted a Comforter in his old Age; and ſhe had been better ſupply'd with one in her Youth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go, you're naught, I'll talk no more with you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay, take me with you, for if you leave me here alone, I ſhall think worſe than I talk.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come along then, Mad-Cap.

div.head: SCENE, Back Door of a Garden.
div.stage: Enter Lady Teſtie, and Betty in their Hoods and Scarfs.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Good dear Madam, don't afflict your ſelf, ſince y'are bound to your Misfortune, reſolve to endure it, and make your ſelf as eaſie under it, as you can; your Grief will make you ſick in earneſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
I wiſh it cou'd, that I might not be troubl'd to diſſemble it; to keep my ſelf from the loath'd Bed of that
old nauſeous Wretch, my Husband; who not contented to Wed me to his wither'd Carkaſs, has alſo forc'd me from London from my Friends, from every thing that might give me Comfort in my Miſery, to dwell here in a Country Town, where nothing is to be ſeen but ſuch as himſelf.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, here's ſomething better to be ſeen then himſelf;—What think you of the Gentleman you ſaw alight yeſterday at the Inn Door, when you ſtood at the Window.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O don't name him, unleſs thou cou'dſt give me another ſight of him; and yet I fear if I had my Deſires, 'twou'd ſerve me only to beget another, and another; ſtill ſucceeding, till I had ask'd my Ruine. Did you enquire who he is?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I did, Madam, but cannot learn; he came from London, and 'tis thought by the People of the Houſe, he ſtays for Horſes, to convey him farther.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Cou'd not ye have contriv'd to have ſpoke to him?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I cou'd, Madam, had you ſo commanded me; but 'to what end?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, thô I wiſh he knew my Heart, and were inclin'd to take me from my Plague my Huſband, who, I'm reſolv'd never ſhall enjoy me, thô I'm ſure to be the unhappieſt of my Sex.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible, Madam, I think, for you to hold out much longer; you ha' kept him this Month (e'er ſince you were Married) from your Bed, with the pretence of Sickneſs, he now grows impatient, and begins to believe 'tis deſign'd thrô the want of Love.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I care not what he believes—ha!—Who's that yonder?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Where, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yonder, coming down the Walk.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: 'Slife, Madam, 'tis the ſtranger we was talking of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Put on your Mask.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Did not you ſay, you had a mind to ſee him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have, and ſpeak to him; but he muſt not ſee my Face; but ſee, he makes this way.
sp.stage: Enter Woodvill, and Jack the Boy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Boy, which is the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, they go in at one of theſe Garden Doors to it; but they are ſo much alike, I can't go directly to it; I'll knock, if you pleaſe, at one of them, and enquire.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What's here? Women, and Mask'd, I thought Vizards had been of no uſe at night, out of London, where they did not ſerve to invite us to a Face that had a mind to be ſeen; Jack, when you have found Sir Thomas Teſties, wait for me at the end of the Walk.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ladies, is not the pleaſure of the Walk loſt, without company?
Not to us, Sir; we think Two enough, and are beſt pleas'd when we are by our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If one of you has hid a different Sex under her Petticoat, I cou'd believe you; but Two Women can only talk themſelves into an Imagination of a Pleaſure; they can never produce without the help of one of us.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay;—What's that, Sir, which we of our ſelves are not able to poſſeſs, without your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Lookyee Child, if you have an inclination to be inform'd, leave your Friend and come with me to the other end of the Walk, and I'll ſhew you preſently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I do nothing without her, Sir; If you can't inſtruct us both together, we'll not Edifie alone.

sp.speaker: Wood
sp.p: Both together;—I'll give you leave to ſeem as ignorant as you pleaſe, if you have a mind not to underſtand me; but don't put me upon impoſſibilities;—If you'll retire with me one at a time, I'll promiſe you ſhall be both ſatisfy'd, before I leave you.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: But how ſhall we be ſore you'll keep your Promiſe? Have a care you don't put your ſelf upon impoſſibilities.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Egad that's true too; I think I have been a little too forward; but come my Dear, what I want in Power, you ſhall find I have in Will, therefore don't loſe time.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Who do ye ſpeak to?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Aye; ſuppoſe we had a mind to take you at your word, which of us wou'd you chuſe firſt? for I don't ſee yet to which you are inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay Gad, that I can't tell; unleſs you agree to pull off your Masks, you keep my Fancy in the dark.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And 'tis too light I think to ſhew our Faces, after the liberty we have taken—How, or which way ſhall I contrive to keep him? If he leaves me now, perhaps I may never ſee him more; and he has ſtaid too long already, to part with him for ever; think quickly, what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I can't tell how to adviſe you, Madam, unleſs you take him this back way into the Houſe with you; when we have him there, we ſhall have more time to conſider what's beſt to be done.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! What are they doing, drawing Cuts who ſhall be firſt ſerv'd; Ladies, pray let no Diſpute ariſe between you upon my Account; I'm reſolv'd to goe with her that's neareſt my own temper; let the coldeſt Conſtitution withdraw, till the other and I have been a little better acquainted, and then—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold—Hold, Sir—Don't raiſe you Expectation too high, thô the freedom we have given our ſelves, may cauſe a ſuſpicion of our Conduct, you will not find us to be what you imagine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for that; Are you what you ſeem to be, Women?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, but not fit for your Converſation, for we are Honeſt, yet were we willing to be otherwiſe, our Age wou'd want a Charm to provide for us.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Honeſt,—and Old—What, do ye ſtudy al
• ays to my Courage, before I come to ingage—Ha!—Here's a plump ſmooth Arm; and your Speech
does not betray any want of Teeth; and ſo far I'm ſure, you are Young enough.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You'r Ear has deceiv'd you then; for I want all my Teeth but three.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If you had two leſs than you have, I'm ſure you have a Colt's-tooth, as long as there's a Stump left; therefore that ſhall be no hindrance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, I ſay, where wou'd you have me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Have thee, Child, why to the next Green Bank we come at: 'Tis true, the Place is not ſo well, as I cou'd wiſh it; but Love will make hard ſhifts.—See your Friend knows your Mind, ſhe keeps her diſtance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forbear; and if it is in your Power to behave your ſelf like a Gentleman, follow me, and as you ſhall deſerve expect a Return; But firſt, for your Inſtruction, know you muſt put a Conſtraint upon your temper, and ſeem Virtuous, which I believe will coſt you ſome pain to do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Seem Virtuous What a Pox do's ſhe mean by Cramping of me?—Hark'ye Child, do's your Friend uſe to task her Lovers, as Conjurers do the Devil, with things Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Whatever task ſhe deſigns for you; 'tis ſuch, I believe you'd very willingly go through, if you knew the Reward wou'd follow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo; I'gad I'll endeavour to gueſs, to Incourage me.

l.hi: Whate'er it is; it can't but eaſie prove,
Enjoyn'd by Beauty, and repaid with Love.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: HOwe'en you'r pleas'd to reproach me, Madam, I beg you'll think better of my Love; than to believe it has a Thought beyond your ſelf: 'Tis true, I ask'd you of your Father; But I ask't nothing elſe but you, that he might witneſs for me to the World how much beyond it I preferr'd you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well; I'll not enquire any farther what your Reaſons were; but whoever has me muſt receive me from my own Gift, and conſequently without a Portion; for Sir Thomas parts with nothing that he can keep to himſelf; therefore, think before 'tis too late, how Love and Marriage may agree with you, where there is a Fortune wanting to ſupport it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I beſeech you, Madam, If I am not wholly loſt in your Eſteem, name it not; I have Eſtate enough to make us both happy, if Fifteen hundred Pounds a Year, and an Unexhauſted ſtock of Love can do it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well; for once I'll try to believe you; and in the mean time, take this Confeſſion, which I did not deſign ſo ſoon ſhould a ſpoke my Inclinations, if I am not yours on thoſe Conditions, I here promiſe never to be anothers.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O ſay that again; that the Sound may dwell in my Ears, and the buſineſs of my Life ſhall become my ſtudy to repay it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: O Madam, Madam, Sir Thomas has been enquiring for you all over the Houſe, and has ſent me and the reſt of the Servants to look for you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Unhappy Chance! Speak, my Soul, when ſhall I ſee you again?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I know not;—When next I hear from you, If I can, I'll ſend you, word, till then—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ten thouſand Angells dwell with my Love.
Boy, where's your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I left him here, Sir, when I came to you; and he order'd me to come to him to the end of the Walk, but I can't find him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Our ſtaying ſo long, I believe, has tyr'd his Expectation. Come, let's go home.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Teſtie and Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Patience! What do'ſt thou preach Patience to me for, when thou know'ſt I have not ſo much left, as will ſtay the Roaſting of an Egg.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Had you as much as wou'd go to the building of Pauls, I'm afraid you wou'd have occaſion for it.

It's very true, indeed, Sir, I muſt needs ſay, but where there's no Remedy, we muſt bear it: Alas! my poor Lady has a double Portion of Sorrow; Firſt from her Sickneſs, and next to be kept from your Embraces, for ſure, Sir, whatever you are pleas'd to think, I'm confident ſhe loves you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Doſt thou think ſo; I wiſh ſhe'd give me a Reaſon to think ſo, for to me her ſickneſs ſeems Apocryphal; ſhe'll take nothing, though the Doctors and Apothecaries every Day ſend in as many Pots and Glaſſes, as would Kill or Cure a whole Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, Her weak Stomach loaths every thing that's offer'd her, if it has but the Name of Phyſſick.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, what's to be done then?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p:
Sir, She has to day, through my perſuaſion taken a Cordial to ſtrengthen her Stomach; and if to Night
I can but get her to uſe ſomething that's prepar'd for her, it will put her kindly to reſt, and make her clear another Woman by the Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say'ſt a ſo, my Girl; How thou reviv'ſt me What is't? Prithee tell me, what it is?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: That your Worſhip ſhall know time enough; for if it agrees with her, it muſt be your Care hereafter to ſee that ſhe has it often, or it will indanger a Relapſe; In the mean time, Sir, your beſt care will be to Command the Family early to Bed; for if ſhe be diſturb'd in its Operation, it may prove of dangerous Conſequence.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee, my Girl, not a Dog in the Houſe ſhall dare to wag his Tail after ſhe's in her Chamber; but pri • hee ſee that ſhe has enough of it; and if ſhe ſhews any diſguſt in the taking of it, bid her think of me, and that for my ſake ſhe muſt be prevail'd upon.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, If ſhe has the Pleaſure (I ſhou'd have) in uſing an Old Man as he deſerves, ſhe'll not forget ye; Though ſhe'll have a ſtronger Motive to think of ſomething elſe, when ſhe's in the Arms of a Young Fellow that ſhe likes.—Pray leave every thing to my management, and good Sir, be going early to Bed, and pray our Endeavours may proſper.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Pray—Ay, Ay; Thou needs not fear but I'll pray, and I hope my Prayers will be heard, for I am not often troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: So—I hope I've ſecur'd my Ladies pleaſure, without the Fear of being diſturb'd; Now to prepare the matter.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Teſtie, led in by Flora and Lucia.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Oh,—lead me to a Chair; Oh, Oh,—Betty, come hither.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Will your Ladiſhip be pleas'd to have any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, no; Nothing but a little more Air, if you pleaſe. Oh,—Oh,—where is Sir Thomas, I thought I heard him with you, when my Fit took me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Madam; If you pleaſe we'll ſend for him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, 'tis no matter;—My Diſtemper is ſuch, it makes me fancy I ſee him oftner than I do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I believe you ſee him oftner then you wiſh.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may be ſure of it; Can any Woman look upon a Husband of his Years, without fancying ſhe's taking leave of the World; were I in 〈◊〉 Condition, 'twou'd make me ſet the Sexton to Work without the help of a Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh—Oh—. (aſide to Betty.) What have you done with the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I've diſpos'd him, Madam, as you bid me; but I fear it will be Impoſſible to conceal him there till bed time, from every body's knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know it. Sir Thomas therefore I deſign ſhall ſee him, and bid him Welcome.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Slife, here comes my Father, Lucia! How ſhall I avoid him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The beſt way as I know, is to take your Hoels, Floria.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How now! What are you ſcar'd at the ſight of me? Come back here Gentlewoman, come back I ſay, thou Pimple of the Primitive Itch; that like thy Grandmother Eve, will eat of no Fruit but what's forbidden thee; Pray, when is it forſooth, that we are to dance at your Wedding, hah?—Have you got the Man in the Mind yet, you are ready I know, let him come when he dares.

sp.speaker: Flo Sir,
sp.p: I'm never ready to do any thing I ought not to do; If I have receiv'd the Addreſſes of Mr. Friendly, 'twas becauſe I thought I ſaw nothing in him, that you cou'd diſapprove, and his Love and Fortune claim'd that return I but juſtly made him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
God ſo, Madam; I beg your Pardon, get you to him then, if you think ſo; Go, get you gone to him then as faſt as you can go; and let the Parſon mumble ye together, that you may dance your Matrimonial Jigg without loſs of time. Do you long to be Moulding of Cockeldebread, hah; get you out of my ſight, Huſſey, go; Hold, now I think again, you ſhall not go, you ſhall ſtay here and
hang at my Girdle like a Horn-Book, till I have learnt ye through.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: You'd ſooner crack your Brains with her, Old Gentleman; that I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But here,—here is my greateſt Grief, all my other Afflictions are doubl'd and trebl'd in this one; and this will ſink me to the Grave; How doſt thou my Love? Is there no hopes of Comfort? Muſt I for ever live without the uſe of my ſelf; or, like Tantalus, have the Meat at my Noſe, and yet be forbid to Eat.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: We muſt endeavour to be ſatisfy'd, my Dear a little time will, I hope, reſtore me to my Health; you muſt needs think it is an equal trouble to us both, tho' my Sex forbids me to expreſs ſo much of it as you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say'ſt-a ſo; then I will be ſatisfy'd, if thou doſt love me, I'll wait with more Patience than a Patriarch for thee.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You ſhall not need, Sir, I hope, if my Lady will be but rul'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O my Dear, this importunate Wench wou'd not let me alone, till I had promis'd to take ſomething to night, that ſhe had provided for me; thô I fear the very ſight of it will diſorder me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The ſight of it; why, what need you look upon it, take it in the dark; and if you can but get it into your Mouth, conſider the good it will do you, and I'll warrant you'll get it down, therefore pray take it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why then I will my Dear, ſince you will have it ſo, pray come hither and lead me in; but hold, I have ſomething to ſay to you firſt; Betty has been a very good Girle, and for that reaſon I will forbear to chide her, for her fault in admitting a Man to my Houſe, with any deſign, without my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A Man! What doſt thou mean, hah? What Man, hah? What Man?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: What Man, Sir—Why—a.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, and don't go about to excuſe it.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: With all my Heart; for I'm ſure I'm at a loſs to juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Twas a fault, knowing how much Sir Thomas and I are your Friends; and wou'd rather promote a a good Husband for you; than he your hindrance▪

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Say you ſay—Lies the Game there—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Gentleman, my Dear (for ſo it ſeems he is, and the only Son of a very good Family) has for tun'd to fall in Love with this fooliſh Girl, and comes unknown to them to Court her for a Wife; therefore pray Sir Thomas, if you can be any ways aſſiſtant in forwarding the matter, do it in conſideration of her faithful Service to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: With all my Heart—Betty—Let me ſee him, and his Love ſhall not want incouragement, and if, my Life, thou doſt recover thy Health, I'll make her a Fortune that ſhall deſerve a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go Betty, bring him hither— (Aſide.)—and be ſure you caution him how to behave himſelf, but keep him ſtill, in ignorance of us and our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I will, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What a dear Friend Diſſimulation is to a Woman, how many mouldy Kiſſes has it ſav'd my Mother-in-law, from my Fathers old bruſh Beard.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, d'ye think ſhe diſſembles?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Aye, as ſure as thou do'ſt, when you cry you'll never Marry, and had rather have me for a Bed-fellow, than a Man.
sp.stage: (Betty goes to her Lady, and whiſpers.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis well they have taken pity of me, and ſuffer'd me to breath in a larger Room; I wiſh they may have Charity to reward my Sufferings, for I have been thruſt into ſuch a hole, that no body but a Beau, who fear'd being drub'd for Cuckoldom cou'd a hid himſelf in it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How! Not ſpeak to him, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Bett
sp.p: I cou'd not, 'twas impoſſible, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Odds ſo, a very handſome young Fellow; Sir, your Servant, y'are welcome, very welcome; and had I ſeen you before, and known your intent of coming hither,
your Reception ſſiou'd not a been conceal'd, what ever your Love was.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Reception and Love, What a Pox does the Old Fellow mean, my Fairy Miſtreſs, I pickt up by Moon-ſhine, has not brought me here, ſure, to make a Jeſt of me: (Looking on Floria and Lucia.) Ha! there they are by this light a Couple of pretty Creatures; Now wou'd I part with any thing butmy Manhood to know which of 'em I'm firſt to have a Fall with; for by their Diſcourſe, I found they had both a mind to try my ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I perceive by the Lovers Silence, my Unkle has put him out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He looks like a likely Fellow; if he does not want a Tongue, Betty has made a good choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you ſeem ſurpriz'd that I'm privy to this matter; don't fear, I'm a Friend to her you love, and for her ſake will aſſiſt you in this Buſineſs, farther than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Egad, may be ſo, and perhaps farther than I deſire; I Thank you, Sir, But however you came by your Knowledge, if ſhe that brought me here, had been as wiſe as ſhe ought to be, ſhe had known you were no more fit to be acquainted with my Buſineſs, than you are to do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir; perhaps I miſtake your Buſineſs, I thought 'twas Honourable, 'twas ſo repreſented to me; Sir, if it is otherwiſe, there's the Door, 'tis as wide as 'twas when you came in, you ſhall have no Coupling here, if you come not I God's name.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What does the old Blade mean, and who a Plague does he take me for?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Sir, as you hope to have a happy end of this Adventure, Humour my Maſter's miſtake, and ſeem to be what he'd have you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What he'd have me—What's that—I—I—
sp.stage: (Looking on the Maid, and ſometimes on Sir Thomas.
sp.p:
ask your pardon—Sir,—if l've been unmannerly—I thought my Deſign had been conceal'd, but ſince it has come to your Knowledge, I hope you'll be my Friend as
you've promis'd, for there is but few I care to truſt with a Secret of this Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The fewer the better; what need any body know of it, but we that are preſent; but to prevent what may happen if they ſhou'd let us come to a concluſion, What ſay you, will you to Bed together preſently?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir, this Minute if you pleaſe. (Aſide.) I-Gad this will be rare; I wiſh I knew how theſe witty Rogues have plotted to gain the Old Man's helping Hand, to the Friendly Office of Pimping for me. But I find my Buſineſs is not to be inquiſitive; I'm only to ſuffer my ſelf to be led to the Feaſt; and when every thing is prepar'd, then fall to.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Huzzy, and ſay no more; it ſhall be as I'de have it—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed my Dear I think ſhe's in the right; ſo ſuddain, and at this time of Night; it will not be decent.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Decent; Fiddle Faddle; ſtrick while the Iron's hot; many accidents fall between the Cup and the Lip; if ſhe don't know what's good for her ſelf, I do; ſhe'll make me a Curt'ſie for it to Morrow Morning, and Than] me; go go, preſently to Amen the Clerk, and bid him bring Mr. Small Tythes, the Vicar.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Vicar, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye? Why?—He'll do it as well as the Parſon.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I-Gad, but he ſhan't, Thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Goe, Goe Girle, make haſte, when tis done, 'tis done, you know.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, and I know any thing the Parſon does, is not to be undone by any body but the Hangman, and I'm not ready yet for eigher of their Noozes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So, my Spark has made a fine hand on't; he has ſpoil'd his Part by over acting it.—Betty, think of ſome way as you go along to bring himoff again.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: If I ſhou'd, I fear he'd be gravell'd again, for 'tis Impoſſible he ſhou'd find his way thus in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Now I think again, Sir—a—a—a—I muſt intreat you defer this matter till a Canonical hour; for I'm under an Obligation to a Deceas'd Grand-mother,
not to marry out of one; and tho Dead I durſt not diſobey her Commands.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid; I love thee the better for't: But prithee let it be ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The ſooner the better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What ſay you, to morrow Morning then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my Heart.—By that timeſure I may hope to be able to expound this Riddle.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very well. Niece and Daughter, entertain the Gentleman, while I wait on my Wife to her Chamber, and I'll be with you again preſently, Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Betty, hearken to their Diſcourſe; and if any ſhou'd happen to our prejudice, be ready to ſtep in, and break it off.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wiſh that Old Fellow had not taken his Wife away with him; for my Temper at this time has inclin'd my Heart more to the making of Cuckolds, than the Deſtruction of Maiden-heads.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now for a formal Bow, and a ſet Speech; theſe Country Sparks approach all Women as they do their Godmothers, when they ask 'em bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Luo.
sp.p: I believe you'r miſtaken, Floria; I fancy that Air will produce ſomething more than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I ſhou'd a fancy'd ſo too, if he had not made Love to my Mother's Maid.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now the Enemy is drawn off, Ladies, I hope we come to a Cloſe Parley again; for ſince I have ſeen your Faces, it has coſt me more Pain to hold my Tongue, than 'twou'd a Maid of Forty, when ſhe was bid ſay after a Parſon for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Say you ſo; Well, and now 'tis at Liberty, what have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Nay, Gad, I think not much, for we were agreed in a manner before we came hither; and what remains now, is to be done, Child, and not ſaid.—Come, ſet aſide that Improper Face upon the Matter, and ſhew me the way to your Chamber; I know you like me, or
you wou'd not a taken ſo much pains to a brought me here

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a Pox do they laugh at?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Prithee Couſin, what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, I muſt ask you that, who brought him here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I bring him here!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Poch; You brought me here between you, and you ſhall ſhare me between you as far as I can go; therefore prithee let us Underſtand one another without more a do

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You may laugh, Ladies; but if you force me away with your Jeſt, I'gad you ſhall cry for me, before you have me again.

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good, Sir, have a Modeſter Opinion of your ſelf, than to believe the loſs of you wou'd coſt either of us one Tear, though we were thoſe very kind Fools you ſay we are.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir; We are not ſo inamour'd of your ſweet Sex, (thô we muſt own here's a Scarcity in this Place) to weep for any Man, thô he promis'd more to recommend himſelf, than any of your Mothers making.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pray Madam, don't diſparage my Mother's Huſwifery; I think this Leg with the true proportion of my Body, ſhews ſhe made as good Inſtruments to raiſe Succeſſion to the Family, as any Dutiful Wife in the Pariſh; and let me tell you, if you were not worſe than an errant Widow, you'd ſay ſo too, but 'tis no matter; ſuch as I am, I ſhall find ſomebody will know what it is to be thankful for me, and for them only will I keep my ſelf, and ſo Ladies your Servant.

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Perhaps you think I won't go.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sure he's Mad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I believe ſo too; Good, Sir, let me ask y • one
Queſtion. You ſeem to be very well acquainted with us; Pray how long is it ſince, and where did our acquanitance firſt begin?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come along with me, and I'll ſhew thee the Place preſently; and as forgetful as you ſeem to be now, if I don't give thee Reaſon to Remember it theſe Nine Months, I'm a Capon.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'm afraid I've ſtaid a little of the longeſt. Sir, perhaps you'r weary with riding, and had rather be a-bed; if you pleaſe I'll light you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He does talk indeed as if he wanted ſleep.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Madam, I believe my Lady will want you and Madam Lucia's help, for ſhe's grown exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I rather believe, Gentlewoman, you want our abſence; which ſhou'd we afford you, I fear will give you occaſion to be worſe than you ought to be

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Pray, what d'ee mean, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Your pretended Lover here wears too thin a Diſguiſe to paſs upon us, thô he has upon my Father; a Gentleman of his Senſe is ſeldom ſo fond of Marriage, to have ſuch an honourable deſign upon a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha; what's the Meaning of this? I honourable deſigns upon any body!

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you don't think I'd admit of any Thoughts but what are ſo, I'm ſure, Sir, if you have any you never own'd them to me, therefore pray Winking on him. don't let your Carriage be ſuch as may make the Young Ladies, or any body elſe believe I wou'd ſuffer any evil Proceedings; and if you think ſo, you'l find your ſelf miſtaken, I'll tell you that, for all I'm a Poor Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Devil's at Work for me, I find, by this Wenches winking, but what I muſt do or ſay to help the matter forward, I'm a Dog if I can tell.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Sir, my Wife continues very ill, and I cannot wait on you, but I hope you'll be ſo kind to Command
my Houſe however; Betty, ſee the Gentleman has every thing that's fit to make him welcome: Come Girls, come here's no buſineſs for you, therefore leave the Lovers to themſelves, come.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sir, be pleas'd to leave us here; and we'll wait upon you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: To what end forſooth?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sir, we have ſome reaſons to ſuſpect this Gentleman's pretenſions to Betty; and before, we leave him alone with her, my Couſin and I will enquire, if you pleaſe, a little more into the Truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Humph—You enquire—What—What would you enquire? ha!—What wou'd you enquire?—What a mighty concern you have for every Morſel that goes by your own Mouth; You enquire—You have ſuch an Itch to know how matters ſtand towards Matrimony; you are for examining every body how 'tis with them—Pray walk in, Pray do,—You enquire.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Harkee Damſel, you that can tell, now the Coaſt is clear—Pray let me know what's my buſineſs here; and and how am I to be employ'd to Night?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: What your Buſineſs will be, Sir, I can only gueſs; but mine is to light you to a good Bed, and clean Lumen; a Bed-fellow I can't promiſe you, but ſhou'd you happen to find one you like, I hope you'll remember your Benefactor.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well hinted that I will, and to aſſure thee I'll keep my word, there's earneſt for thee;—But may not I gueſs who this may be?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: That you may, Sir, and be deceiv'd;—But if you hit the Nail on the Head, I muſt not tell you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come, thou ſhalt tell me; and tell me againſt thy Will; I'll • orce thee to't—

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I muſt not indeed, Sir, but if you'll follow me, I will endeavour to carry you, where you ſhall inform your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Wilt thou, that's better ſtill;

l.hi: Sure at the laſt we ſhall this Clew unwind,
At leaſt the Ball if not the Bottom find.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I Wiſh I cou'd gueſs where my Friend is: If we were in London, I ſhou'd believe ſome Petticoat Companion had pick't him up; but here's no Traders; and for any other Woman, he has not had time to fit her for his uſe:—Robin, bid that Country-fellow without come to me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hob, Can'ſt thou carry this Letter to Sir Thomas Teſties Houſe for me?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do ſo; and give it to Madam Flora; but take care no Body ſees you deliver it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—But muſt I car it to Night, 'tis very dark?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You muſt go immediately.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I hope Sir, there's no difference between you and Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why do'ſt thou hope ſo?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, I do hear there is; and if ſo, I ſhan't greatly care to meddle or make between Friends, that I muſt tell you, for 'tis but an unthankful Office; beſides, you know Sir Thomas is a Man that's very curſt; and if he do's but reſpect I concern my ſelf between you, may hap he may take the Law of me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Piſh, the Law of thee, no, no, I'll ſecure thee from any harm.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, very well, that's as much as I can deſire; but pray don't take unkindly what I ſay; for you know no Man is willing to bring himſelf into a primunire if he can help it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, no, prithee be gone.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I will, Sir, I will—for▪for—Pray, Sir, be pleas'd to read the Subſcription for me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, how I'm tortur'd with this fooliſh Fellow? and I can ſend no Body elſe, without being ſuſpected; don't trouble thy ſelf with the Superſcription, but deliver it as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Very good, Sir, very good;—'tis main dark; Wou'd it not do as well, Sir, if I ſhou'd car it in the Morning?—I had rather carry it in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, I'll tell you;—At the lower end of Sir Thomas's Orchard, one of our poor Neighbours, being in a diſpariging condition, has gone and Hang'd himſelf:—Now there is ſome does ſay who have ſeen him, how that he walks by Night in ſeveral ſhapes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What, and ſo you're afraid, are you?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I'm not afraid, I thank Providence, I defie the Devil, and all his Works.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Pox upon thee then, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Tho' I muſt tell you, I have a great conceit that he will appear to me; for you muſt know, to Morrow the Crowner's Queſt do's ſit upon him, whereof, de'e ſee, I am to be one; and who knows but he may have ſomething upon • is Spirits that may make him break his Mind to me; and if ſo—Let me tell you, I'm afraid it will make a bad Day for ſome Body: For if Sir Thomas had kept his Fences whole, may hap this Man had never been tempted to 'a gone into his Ground to 'a Hang'd himſelf: But be it as it will, I'll do your Buſineſs for you; therefore pray take you no care, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prithee about it then.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I'll warrant you, I'll warrant you, don't trouble your ſelf no further.

div.head: SCENE II. Room, Table, Book and Candle.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Adventures of this kind, that look with the face of a Reward, make Expectation great and uneaſie; but mine has been ſo often jilted, ſince I've been here, I begin to wiſh it Morning, that I might go home and laugh at my ſelf for my damn'd impertinent Curioſity—Yet methinks this Buſineſs ſhou'd not end ſo, if this Virgin, Wife, or Widdow, or what the Devil ſhe is I know not, (that do's trick me) ſhou'd ſuffer me to ſleep to Night, with a bare Pillow in my Arms; may ſhe have the Curſe of always lying alone, and never know the uſe of a Bedfellow. [Sees a Book on the Table.] How now, what's here, a Book? As I'm a Whore-maſter, an errant Pray'r-Book: Let me ſee what Title do's it bear—The Crums of Comfort—A Plague of your Dyet;—Is that feeding for a Gentleman?—Now have I a good mind to read and be Converted; fall a ſinging of Pſalms, and diſturb the whole Family;—But that's to mortifie my ſelf now I think on't; I'll e'en go to Bed, and try to forget 'em.
sp.stage: [Puts out the Candle, and is going to Bed.
Enter Lady Teſtie, in a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: So, now the Candles out, I may with ſafety venture:—Sir,—Sir,—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'm come for Satisfaction for a Wrong you've done in coming hither to ſeduce my Miſtreſs from me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs; Who are you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then good Gentleman, go and fetch a Light, and you ſhall have what you come for preſently; tho' the Devil take me, if I'm acquainted with either thee or thy Miſtreſs that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, there needs no Light, the Dark is fitter for my Revenge, therefore guard your ſelf as well as you can, for I have more Swords than my own to aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! Then I fear I'm fallen into the hands of a Villain, not of a Gentleman; but come, I'm bound to try it, come on.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold a little, 'Sliſe if he ſhou'd make me ſmart for my fooling, 'twou'd make but an ill Jeſt;
Pray, Sir, ſuſpend your Fury a while, here will happen no danger, unleſs you apprehend any from a Woman.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Woman!—I thought indeed the Voice did not found very much like a Hero's,—But how ſhall I know you're a Woman? You've accoſted me but odly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can't you tell how to find that out?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I don't know faith, I cou'd a done; I'll try.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray put up your Weapon firſt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, that I will; I think this is too ſharp for a Womans uſe, But why came you in the Dark?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For fear you ſhou'd not like me in the Light.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It muſt be a very ill Face that can't recommend it ſelf to one Nights Lodging—Prithee let me take a Kiſs to ſweeten my Imagination however: [Kiſſes.]—Ha,—A plump ſmooth Lip, and a Breath ſweet as a new pluck't Roſe;—Now ſay thou'rt a Blackamoor if thou wilt, for nothing after this can turn my Stomach.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where are you pulling me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pulling thee, why to Bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, not ſo faſt;—I'm come reſolv'd to give my ſelf wholly to you, but e're I do ſo, you muſt promiſe me ſomething to deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That I will; my Dear, any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But will you perform what you promiſe?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Don't doubt it; What is it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To eſteem this Favour, as it is the firſt I ever granted to any, and in return ſwear, to love me as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Humph—That's a little hard, before I ſee your Face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: When I think ſit to ſhew it you, and it prove not a Tolerable one, you ſhall be diſſolv'd from your Oath.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's fair, as a Man can deſire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Swear then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I do; By the dear Pleaſure I'm going to poſſeſs; upon that Condition, I ſwear to love thee, and only thee, to the end of my Life.— (Aſide)—Whatever we believe of a Woman before Enjoyment, we ſeldom like 'em ſo well to think 'em tolerable after it; ſo there's no great fear of my being forſworn; Come, dear Rogue, come.

sp.speaker: Lady—
sp.p: What a lightneſs do I wear to ſeem the thing I am not? Love is too powerful in me to be this Airy thing he takes me for, and before I leave him, I fear I ſhall betray it, which yet I wou'd not do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What means this Pauſe Child? I hope no fooliſh Qualms to check your Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, Sir, Only a few Ejaculations before I go to Execution; and now diſpoſe of me as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then Heaven have mercy upon thy Soul, for I ſhall have little on thy Body.
sp.stage: [Pulls her, and the Scene ſhuts upon 'em.
Enter Sir Thomas in a Night-Gown, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Are you ſure no Body has been here, to ſpeak with my Daughter from Mr. Friendly?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not that I know of, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No; nor no Meſſenger ſent from my Daughter to him?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I can't tell, Sir; I did not ſee any.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, ſtand you here and watch, till towards Morning, and ſee if you can obſerve any Body walking about the Houſe, whiſtling at the Windows, or crying Hiſt! Ten to one I ſhall have my Blade a Evesdropping by and by, or ſome Body from him; but it ſhall go hard but I'll ſpoil their buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Sir,—Yonders ſome Body with a Light coming down the Field.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Stand ſtill then, and obſerve.
sp.stage: Enter Hob, with a Candle and Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: So;—This is the Houſe;—Now let me ſee, how ſhall I go about to do this ſame buſineſs? if this Old Fox Sir Thomas, ſhou'd chance to ſpy me, he'll maul me for certain: But let me alone, I'll be cunning enough for him, I'll warrant me; if he ſees me, he muſt have more Eyes then two—Hold,—hold,—Now let me ſee for this ſame Letter;—Oh, here it is;—For Madam Flo —Flo—Madam Flora.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Where are you carrying this Letter Friend?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Letter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Letter, Sir,—aye Letter, Who did you bring it from?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bring it from, Sir; I brought it from no Body, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How came you by it?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: By it, Sir?—Why I found it in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Found it in your Pocket;—What did it grow there?—Ha?—Where are you going with it?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Going with it, Sir;—I don't know where I was going with it, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What d'ee here at this time of Night?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I can't tell what I do here, Sir, not I;—I'll go home, Sir, if you pleaſe:—God buy t'ee, Sir;—I wiſh you a good Night:

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold,—hold a little, Friend; let me reward you firſt for bringing of it however.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Not a Farthing, Sir, indeed, I muſt not take one Farthing; for Mr. Friendly charg'd me to the contrary, therefore pray don't offer it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: O ho—Did he ſo? But ſomething I will give you however; pray take that, and that, and that Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O Lord—O Lord—What d'ee ſtrike me for? What d'ee ſtrike me for? A fore God I'll take the Law of yee, ſee an I dont; What d'ee go to Murder me?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'll Law yee,—you Rogue;—Are you their Letter Carrier? There's more for you, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bare Witneſs—bare Witneſs;—ſee an you don't pay for this; O Lord! O Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, ſee him out of my Ground.
sp.stage: Enter Woodvil and Lady as from Bed.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O Night, thou darling Friend to active Love, keep ſtill thy Mantle ſpread, and hide us from the World. Beauty needs no light but its own, to ſee the way to Joy;—Why?—Oh!—Why my Love, will you be gone ſo ſoon? The few ſhort hours we've lov'd, has given us but a taſte of what we might poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do not ask me more than I'm willing to give; what I have already done, might ſure convince you that I had rather ſtay had I not more weighty Reaſons ſo ſoon to leave you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Go not till the Day is broke.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That you may ſee my Face;—Go, I ſhou'd chide your Ungrateful Curioſity; Will you contribute nothing to ſpare my Bluſhes? Think what I've done, the Jewel I have parted with; and no ſecurity for your faith, but a promiſe of a moment's growth, what ſhou'd 'a been deareſt to me, like a Toy, I've thrown away; and to compleat me wretched, you may deſire my Ruine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Can it be your Ruine to make my Happineſs compleat?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Whilſt I'm Conceal'd, ſhou'd you prove unkind, 'twould rob me but of Life; but if Expos'd; take from me, Life and Reputation.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You allay my ſatisfaction, when you doubt my Love, and both that and Honour tie me to ſecure your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you have either, I conjure you do not ask it any more; when 'tis fit you ſhou'd know me better, Love of it ſelf will betray me to you;—for 'twill not be in my power to conceal my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tell me then, when I ſhall be ſo bleſt?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I cannot; but if in the mean time, it will ſtay your Curioſity to be admitted here another Night, perhaps I may be perſwaded to Morrow or next Day to write to you, till then farewell; I know your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O do not ſtay till the next day, let it be to Morrow, and to Morrow, and every Morrow; let every day be fed with Expectation of the approaching Night, and every Night like this; but with a more laſting Ecſtaſie.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How unwillingly my Legs convey me hence; and yet they trembl'd when they brought me here; my Virgin fears hang heavy on my Limbs, and feebl'd all my Joynts! O Love how ſtrange are all thy ways! With dread thou leadſt us where we long to be, and when poſſeſt of what we come for, with double pain conveys us back again.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Prithee don't rail at him any more; thou haſt done enough already to convince me you love him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I cou'd almoſt be angry with you for ſaying ſo; tho' I know you don't think ſo.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Indeed I do; and ſhou'd he Marry Betty to Day, (as I'm ſure that's but a pretence to farther ſome other deſign, he has in coming here) it would break thy Heart.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You think me very amorous ſure to be ſo ſmitten with a Man at firſt ſight?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You can't help it if you are.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But why d'e think I am?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'll anſwer you with another Queſtion: Why wou'd you not let me ſleep laſt Night for Talking of him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who began it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I did; becauſe I thought the Diſcourſe wou'd pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For what reaſon?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Becauſe all the Evening you did as you do now, Bluſh when any Body ſpoke of him,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who can forbear it, to hear you Talk ſo?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No Body indeed in thy Condition;—Come prithee Lucia don't vail thy Heart from me; for if thou doſt, I'll certainly make thy Caſe known, and tell Betty what a Rival ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I find it is but a folly to ſay any thing to you; but d'ee really think he can be ſo in Love with that fooliſh Girle?—A Man, to all appearance, ſo much above a Thought ſo low, methinks 'tis an Injuſtice to him to believe it, ſuch a Meen and Air in all he ſays and does, ſo free and unaffected his Diſcourſe, it creates a Delight in all that hear him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: His Wit indeed is very engaging.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ay, is it not? And when he addreſſes—Tho' it is not in a ſtile ſo awful as the niceſt Vertue wou'd expect; yet it Charms beyond the Oratory of a God.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why do you Laugh?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Only at your not being in [Lucia holds down her Head, hides her Face with her Fan, and runs away. Love, Madam. What a Tyrant is this little Deity? Not ſatisfy'd with having us poor Virgins in his power, but muſt ſhew us in our Fetters; you need not run away from me Lucia, for if thy Malady encreaſe, the Cordial of a Friends advice will ſoon fetch thee to me again.
sp.stage: As ſhe is going off, Enter.
Enter Hob, and Country People with a Man Dead-Drunk.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Come Neighbours, bring him along, and ſet 'en down here, for he muſt be examin'd, before we part with 'en.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How now Friends; What Body's that you've got?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Body,—This no Body forſooth; this is a Carcaſs, one that was a wicked Body.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why he has Hang'd himſelf.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Alas poor Wretch! What was the Cauſe?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: The Cauſe;—Why he's Marry'd, and has a Wife and ſix Children.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is that a Cauſe for a Man to Hang himſelf? What is he?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: What is he? Why he's a Jacobite, and he Hang'd himſelf, becauſe he would not pay double Taxes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Piſh;—

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Come Neighbour Hob, you that can tell, pray let us know what we are to do.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why we that are the Crowner's Queſt, the Law ſays, muſt enquire how he came by his Death.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: But of whom muſt we enquire?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why, of they that can tell, and no Body knows that ſo well as himſelf.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Well, but he's Dead.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why ay, ſo it ſeems; and he muſt be Bury'd if we ſay he muſt; and if we ſay not, it may be not neither.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: I ſuppoſe that's as we ſhall find him guilty; therefore pray tell me, Neighbour Hob, whether you think a Man that Hangs himſelf, is guilty of his own Death, or no.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why truly that's a hard caſe to judge, Neighbour Clumſey.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: I think now, that he is guilty.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take heed, don't be too raſh;—for your Conſcience muſt be Umper in this Caſe:—Look'ee—I put this Point to you now, Whether every one that Hangs himſelf, is willing to die?

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: I,—I,—Sure he is willing.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Now I ſay no, for may-hap he might he Non Complementus, and if a Man be Non Complementus, he don't know his own Mind.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: That's true indeed; but now being Dead, pray who muſt anſwer the King for the loſs of his Subject?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Marry he that Hang'd his Subject: That was himſelf.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'twas the Halter that hang'd him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Aye, in ſome ſort it did; but that was in ſe Offendendo, for it may be he went to break the Rope, and the Rope held out in his own defence.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But is not this ſame Rope-maker now that made the Rope, in ſome danger?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No, no, the Rope-maker can be in no fault;—for d'ee ſee, when he makes the Rope, he goes backwards, and how can he ſee before, what ſhall follow after?—Nor indeed is the Rope in fault, for may be he might urge the Rope Solus Volence, as the Law ſays,
neither is he himſelf in fault, for may be his Time was come, and he was born to be Hang'd:—Therefore I do conclude that he was Conſcious and guiltleſs of his own Death.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then Neighbour, he may be buried.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O, of great reaſon, always he that is alive muſt die, and he that is dead muſt be bury'd.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yet truly I think in my Conſcience, he does not deſerve to be Bury'd.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O you ſpeak partiouſly Neighbour Puzzle-pace,—not deſerve to be Bury'd, I ſay he deſerves to be Bury'd alive, that ſhall Hang himſelf; therefore don't Take of that.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Well, but what muſt we do with his Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: His Cloaths, why they are the Hangman's.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then he muſt have 'em himſelf.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Hold, hold,—This is a ſhrewd point of Law, and muſt be well handled; Did he make a Will?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No, he dy'd deteſtable.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why then they fall to the right Heir Male; for look'ee d'ee ſee, the Female can inherit no Breeches, unleſs ſhe can prove ſhe wore them in her Husband's Days.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe he has no Heirs at all?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why then they go to the chief Mourner,—and look'ee d'ee ſee, that will be I, I will take his Cloaths; here now I begin with his Cloak,—there now▪let every one take a quarter of him, and I'll follow with doleful Lamentation.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then, we have done Neighbour, have we?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: How dolefully you look Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why, aye; 'tis the faſhion ſo to do; I'm chief Mourner, I muſt be ſad.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Art thou ſure he's Drunk?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I'm ſure I left him Dead-drunk.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Then I believe they take him for the Man you gave out hang'd himſelf in Sir Thomas's Orchard to fright the Boys from ſtealing the Fruit.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I believe ſo too, therefore prithee let us make haſte for fear they bury him alive.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'TIS ſtrange you ſhou'd not ſee her Face, but when you tell me you love her, I muſt laugh at you; what if you have enjoy'd her, 'twas in the dark, and in the ſame minute your fancy painted her a Venus, you might has ſuppos'd her a Dowdy, and yet ha' been more juſt to her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Aye, but I'm never ſuch an Enemy to my pleaſure, to ſuppoſe her the laſt, when I'd more reaſon to believe her the firſt; but
•• unck you miſtake me, if you think 'tis her I love; no, that's impracticable after Enjoyment; dear Rogue, 'tis the Married Woman I told thee of, that has charm'd my heart; and I have ſome reaſon to believe hers is not impenotrable.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, d'eo believe it? You durſt not ſure tell her ſo?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why not, her Complexion promis'd me a hearing, and having an opportunity as I was coming away this Morning, thro' the Garden where ſhe was walking, I ſpoke to her, and told her, the ſeign'd Love I own'd laſt Night for her Servant, was a Plot I had brib'd her Maid to aſſiſt me in, to get an opportunity to confeſs the real one I had for her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very good;—and no doubt but ſhe beliv'd you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: She ſeem'd at firſt a little ſurpriz'd, but before I left her, I prevail'd ſo for, to gain a promiſe to ſee her again; and how much that may conduce to a good concluſion, you may imagine.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How do you know, but this may be the ſame Woman you lay with laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee don't call my Judgment in queſtion; canſt thou believe me ſo raw a Gameſter not to know a Maid from a Married Woman.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I know not what you may do; but I'm ſure 'tis a Secret I'm yet to learn; but come you muſt go along with me, Flora has ſent me word to day will be kept a Wake before their houſe, and if in the Crowd ſhe can get looſe from her Father, we may chance make work for the Parſon.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't, I had rather help you to make work for the Midwife, I don't care to meddle where the Church is concern'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is not that he, ſee.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: It is Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Follow him, and give him this.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: To what end, Madam; you have found him falſe already.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Diſpute not my Commands, but fly. [Ex. Betty. He has undone me, if he leaves me not, which I too juſtly fear; for he has already diſcover'd the Inconſtancy of his Sex, and what he promis'dd me unknown at Night, in the Morning broke to me, when he took me for another.
How now! Did you give it him?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I did, Madam; and he'll ſee you he ſays.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do'ſt not think he ſuſpects me to he her that was with him laſt Night?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p:
No, Madam; but believing me to be confident to both her and you, he has brib'd me to keep you ignorant of each others Loves, and aſſiſt him in your ſeveral In
• rigues.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Perjur'd baſe Villain! Why am I fated to Love, and not the Infection on my Lips, that when his flattery wou'd feal my ruine, he there might meet his own.

div.head: SCENE II. A Fair.
div.stage: Enter Old Hob and his Wife, with Benches to ſet at the Door and Forms.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come, Husband, good now make haſte; the Town will be full of People, before we ſhall get fitted.

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: Don't trouble thy ſelf Wife, every thing within Doors is ready; and there is nothing wanting without but the Sign to be put up, and look'ee, that ſhall be done preſent; Hob—Hob—

sp.speaker: Hob within.
sp.p: What ſay you Father?

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: Go and Tap th'Ale, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Aye, aye Father.

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: There—Now he that will drink good Ale, let e'n come to th'Sign oth'Potlid. Come, Wife, let's to our buſineſs within.
sp.stage: Enter Friendly and Woodvill: Sir Thomas, Flora, and Lucia at the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If theſe Diſguiſes will let us ſtand unſuſpected, we may be able to attempt ſomething to gain my Flora's freedom.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, and loſe thy own.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yonder ſhe is with her pretty friend; and old Argus that ſticks to 'em, like Murder to a troubl'd Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! Are theſe the Jewels of ſuch vertue? One of them I'm ſure has none to boaſt of; nor will the other, I believe, be a Martyr for her Honour.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Now Ned, tell me, How do'ſt like my Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Like her?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, like her?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Very well for a Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, why doſt think I can like her for any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I do, Sir, and think my ſelf happy in my Choice.

sp.speaker: Wood.
