sp.p: I'm glad you'r ſo pleas'd, Sir, I can have her at a clieaper rate.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ha! What dice mean?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not to hear any thing diſhonourably ſpoken of her I Love, tho' by my Friend.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hum— (Aſide)—Nor ought I indeed in honour, if it was ſhe that did me the favour laſt night, tho' it be to my Friend; Come, prithee ſmooth thy Brow, Franck, thou knoweſt I have but a looſe Opinion of all Women, which but ſeldom will let me ſpeak well of any, tho' they deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Good Manners ſhou'd correct that ill Cuſtom in a Gentleman, and for your own ſake, pray be perſwaded to forget it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Grave Sir, I ſhall Edifie— (Aſide)—in the knowledge of my Miſtreſs, I hope, the next time I have her at Blindman's-Buff, or ſhe ſhall keep my Head in the Bag▪

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come Gentlewomen, if you muſt ſee the Paſtime, you may have as fair a Proſpect of 'em here, as you can in the Crowd, and with leſs danger to your Reputations.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Our Reputations! In what can they ſuffer, amongſt ſuch people as reſort here?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why theſe are Men, and fitter for Womens uſe than Finical Fops, that have only the appearance of Men; meer outſides, the ſigns of Men; and ſuch I have known a Woman fond of.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard Sir, we can't be where we like beſt, I think we are at Age to look after our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye, if you had but Grace to take care of your ſelves too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Women at our years, know how to make their choice; or if we did not we are ſeldom inſtructed by ill uſage.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Eh—eh—What,—what are you a chattering Magpye, hee—do you want to have your Leggs at liberty?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If I do, I can have patience; for I ſhan't want it long, unleſs you cou'd confine my inclinations too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Let me come at her,—let me come at her,—what does ſhe prate again to me? You are one to be intruſted with your ſelf indeed, look'e here elſe, witneſs this Letter, I got ſcouting from your Lover to ye; de'e ſee here I can't read it now for want of my Spectacles, but here he ſays how that ſhe has given him a new life, from the laſt favour ſhe was pleas'd to grant him;—Hark'ee Huſſey, what favour was that you were ſo pleas'd to grant him, tell me, for I will know what that favour was?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
What, not by the laſt favour?—Afore God i'll have her ſearch't;—i'll know how far the honour of my Family was concern'd in that laſt favour of hers;—I will Gentlewomen.—And ſure I ſhall find an Expedient too, to keep you aſunder, if Locks,
and Bolts, and Barrs can do it:—Odſo well remember'd, let me ſee if my Doors are all faſt, and then if you can ſhufle Love through the Key-hole, withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Prithee ſee Flor, if I'm not miſtaken, on of thoſe men yonder looks like your lover Friendly in diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And the other the very ſperk that lay here laſt night, I now begin to think Friendly employ'd him about that piece of Knight Errantry; to get news from our enchanted Caſtle, or to try if thou hadſt Chrams enough to engage him to yoke with his friend.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Why d'ee think ſo?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Becauſe there are few men that marry in this Age; but are aſham'd of their fortune; and wou'd therefore draw in as many of their freinds as they can to Countenance their folly as they call it.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: I have a better opinion of your Lover, Flora.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He's oblig'd to ye Madam.
sp.stage: Enter Hob with a blue Apron on.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, Ch'm coming; your Servant Mr. Friendly, I'm glad to ſee you; you'r welcome to'th Fair.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I thank the Honeſt Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I ſhou'd know that Gentleman,—Maſter Woodvill I think.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye Hob, how doſt do?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: O Lord Maſter, how de'e do? Faith I'm glad to ſee you with all my heart; Lord a mercy upon us; how ſtrangly you be grown ſince you have been over-Seas;—Come, pray ſit you down—Maſter Freindly,—Come pray ſtay, and drink one Pott afore you go.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prithee let us ſit down, or this fellows impertinence will make us obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What do'ſt thou do with an Apron Hob?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: A Dod, I put un on but juſt now; Father will do as Meighbours do, and every one it'h Town a moſt ſells Ale on Fair day, but now we ſell ſeveral other ſorts of liquor; and Wine too an occaſion be.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Wine?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye, all ſorts of Wine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sayeſt a ſo, bring us ſome Claret then.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Claret Sir, we've no Claret, we muſt not ſell Claret; 'tis againſt the Law, now you may have ſome of your Port, your red Port now, or your white Port, or ſuch ſort of Stuff.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Such ſtuff as thou haſt then, Prithee bring us.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Yes Sir,— (is going and then turns back.)—Now in my mind Sir,—what d'ee think of a little Sack, a little Sack now, and ſome of your Sugar in't, is main good.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pirthee bring, what thou lik'ſt beſt thy ſelf—For I'm ſure 'twill pleaſe no palate but thy own.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I fear Frank, your project will not anſwer your end, for I ſee no way of getting at the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There is but little hopes indeed Ned, ſince I ſee the doors ſhut, and the old Knight in their Company; fortune may do ſomething unexpectedly to befriend us.
sp.stage: Enter Hob with two Black Potts, a Trencher with Tobacca, Pipes, and Bread and Cheeſe upon it.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming, here Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Where is the Sack?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Sack Sir,—Od I don't know, I thought you ſaid you had rather have Ale—Ale is indeed much wholſomer now, for your Engliſh Stomaches;—for my Part, i'd rather have Ale now; Maſter Woodvill, bite a bit afore you drink:—Come and mean time i'll put a little Sugar i'th Ale; and make it as good as I can for you:—Come Sir, againſt your diſpoſe'd—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thank ye Hob, this fellows kindneſs will poyſon me before I go hence.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not whilſt you have ſuch a Taſter; for I don't ſee that he intends to leave you any.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: A Dod 'tis main good Sir;—will you have tother Pott Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, prithee drink this too, and then fetch us a Couple.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Yes Sir,—I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: above, Come my merry Countrymen, every man take his Laſs, and give us a Dance or two, and then wee'll have the Cudgells, out.
sp.stage: Enter Hob with the Potts of Ale, ſtares on the Dancers and Dance—minds not the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes, an't like your Worſhips, we are all ready, come Scratch ſtrike up.—Dance.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye marry Sir, well done Ralph; ſet to u'n Joane, ſet toe'n.

sp.speaker: Hob's
sp.p: Mother within. Hob, Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming (he Sings) Toll, •• ll, in Mary, Sides all now, ſides all.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hob, Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming Maſter, toll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p:
Ch'm coming, ch'm coming, what a Plague ails my Father trow? and old Fool! Udsbled he makes more a noiſe,—ſet to now, William, ah rarely done; in Mary, O dainty Mary, turn her about now John, now, now, a murrain, you're quite out: Hold, hold, ye are all out, look Ralph ſhou'd a caſt off, and while John had turn'd Mary about, Thomas ſhou'd a led up Nan, and Joan met Ralph at Bottom again, mean while John ſhou'd a ſided with Mary; and then Mary ſhou'd
back to back with Ralph, and then Thomas had come in again in his own place, and ſo all had been right.—Come begin again, ſtrike up ſcratch, Toll, loll, doll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: O. Hob within,
sp.p: Hob, Hob, Where be ye?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming, what the Devil can't you be quiet a bit, toll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Hey day, hey day, this is rare ſport, I God, i'll ſtrap you, ye baſe Rogue you; muſt you be danceing here, and your Mother and I at work.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Hey day! what's the matter now? what, muſt I be beat all the days of my life?

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Ye Graceleſs Rogue, mind your buſineſs then, do ye, yonders your poor Mother within a ſcoreing and a ſcoring till ſhe ſweats again, and no body to draw one drop of Beer:

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I don't care a farthing, I won't draw a drop more if you go to that, do your worſt, and take your Courſe.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Sirrah, come ye in, and don't ye ſtand dancing here, don't ye.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I won't go in, ſo I won't, if that trouble yo, I will Dance, and Dance again—Angerly, toll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Aye thou'rt an untoward Boy as e're was born; Mercy forgive me for begetting the.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Marry come up, what's here to do I trow?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Here's the Cudgells an't like you, will your Worſhip pleaſe to have us begin.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, by all means make haſt Roger, and bring forth the Hatt and the Favour.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: Here it is, an't pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Hang it up there, and he that wiens it, let him wear it. The firſt Sommerſetſhireman that breaks a Head, here's half a Crown for him to drink; and
he that breaks that Rogue Hobs head, ſhall have another.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Shall he—look'e, he that breaks my Head, ſhall have ſomewhat to do, i'll tell you that, let 'en be who he will, he ſhall earn his Money, Ecod ill rib 'en—And look'e, to begin here i'll take up the Cudgell,—And now let the beſt man here, take up tother, an he dare, if he be a Sommerſetſhireman, let 'en be a Sommerſetſhireman,—I ſight for Gloſterſhire; I don't care who knows it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: At him, at him there—What, is there no body dare venture upon him? Neighbour Puzlepate, take up the to 'ther Cudgell.

sp.speaker: Puzzle,
sp.p: Not I 〈…〉 't pleaſe you, I have enough of 'en already, he broke my Head but laſt week.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Roger,—Sirrah, do you take up the Cudgell, and thraſh him, do'e hear—thraſh him ſoundly Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: I can't promiſe that Sir, I'll do my beſt, I'll break his head if I can in Love; and if he breaks mine, much good may do him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is as I cou'd wiſh; If Hob does but get the better of the Combat, the Teſty Knight will certainly be provok'd to come down, and then we ſhall have ſport.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee let's encourage him then; O brave Hob, now for Gloſterſhire Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I warrant ye Maſter, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here Hob, there's an Angel for thee.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And break his head Hob; and I'll give the another.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Don'te fear Maſter, I God I'll noint 'en.

sp.speaker: Rogger,
sp.p: Do if thou canſt; I don't fear thee Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: S'bleed, I'll dreſs thy Jacket; I'll dowſe thy Somerſetſhire Coate for thee.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: Come on then.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Hob.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Roger.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Hob.
sp.stage: Here they play and Hob breaks to'thers Head.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Roger.
All the Clowns Hollow!

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I God I've don't; I've don't Faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Foul, foul, foul.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Fair, fair, fair.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Here take the Hat Hob.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You lye, you Doggs, 'twas foul.
All Clowns Hollow!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Stand upon thy Guard Hob, the Kinght's coming down to thee.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Is a, let 'en come and welcome; here I'll ſtand, I'll take no other than St. George's Guard; if he let's drive at me, Fore-god I'll hit 'en over the Sconce, if he was a Knight of Gold.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Thomas from the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Where are theſe Bumpkins?—Now who dars ſay 'tis fair.
I ſay 'tis foul.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I ſay 'tis fair.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
So is that too
Sir Thomas and Hob fights; Hob break • the Knights Head; the Clowns hollow and cry ſair; then the Knight draws his Sword and beats Hob and the Clowns off.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O brave Knight!
He has beſtirr'd himſelf I ſaith, with as much courage, as if he fought for diſtreſſed Damſels.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So he has I thank him: Here's liberty for you Madam unexpected, if you'll embrace it come down quickly.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your Jaylor's gone Ladies, and the doors open, come down and we'ell knock off your Fetters.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: To put on ſtronger of your own

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not I faith, I'd have every Woman uſe her leggs as ſhe pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So ſhalt thou thy tongue hereafter; But prithee let me Confine it now, for we have no time to talk.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What is it, you wou'd have of me Friendly?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Remember your promiſe Madam; and ſpare that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I don't know what his deſign is Madam; but here's a Parſon planted hard by I can till you, I believe a purpoſe to do miſchief.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I own my promiſe to marry you, but do not remember I ever oblig'd my ſelf to time.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Be it ſtill unlimited, I'll never preſs it againſt your will: All I ask now is, to deliver your ſelf from Bondage.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What ſayſt thou Lucia, ſhall I go?

sp.speaker: Luoi.
sp.p: If I thought you'd take my advice, I'd give it you, but I'm ſure you'll adhere to none but that of running away, therefore prithee make haſte and begone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Farewell then.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: But haſt thou the Conſcience to leave me behind, to be puniſhed for thy ſins?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Aye, if you can have the heart to let me go without ye.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Make haſte Madam, your Fathers returning.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We come, we come, fly good Lucia.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis pity that Marriage ſhou'd be the end of this Adventure, it looks ſo like Whoring; I wiſh the old Fellows Wife had been in their company, to a got me a Stomach to the Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Upon my Knees I ſhou'd receive you Madam; but the place—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Will not let us loſe time in talking—where's my Couſin? Where's my Couſin?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Leave her to my Friends charge—He's an honeſt Gentleman, and will take care of her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Pox of your honeſt Commendations, let me ſpeak for my ſelf, Madam, here's your Man.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: What to do? Not to follow our Friends example I hope.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No faith Child, I'm better principl'd; thou ſhalt have me upon eaſier Terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: There—there you Ruſtich Rogues,—you hard headed Doggs, I think I've at laſt met with your Sculls; I believe I have notch't ſome of your Noddles for you; I have made you pay for ſhedding my Blood.
sp.stage: Enter a Maid and Roger, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: Oh Sir, Sir, We're undone, Madam Flora and Madam Lucia.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What of them?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: They are gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Gone where?

sp.speaker: Roger
sp.p: With a Couple of Gentlemen Sir, No body knows where.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The Devil go with 'em—which way are they gone?

sp.speaker: Servant,
sp.p: They have taken towards the Road Sir, but they can't be got far.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Bid every one of your fellows take Horſe immediately, and ride ſeveral ways;—Have they ſlipt through my fingers at laſt.—Make haſte you Doggs—(beats 'em) make haſte fly, fly.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p:
If reaſon had a power in Love, I ſhou'd not fann this fire within me, to make a Ruin of my Peace,—But oh I ſtrive in vain, my ungoverned paſſion
drives me on, though ſure Deſtruction follows me: What is't a Clock?

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: Four Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Look if you can ſee him coming.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: He's juſt here Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: O cou'd he bring a heart like that hee'l find here; how happy would this meeting be?—But that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So much for my honeſt obligation; we have hous'd they Lads; my friends buſineſs is done:—Now let me look after my own—; 'tis ſomething paſt the time,—ha!

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: You ſee Sir, how much you have prevail'd upon me, am I not punctual?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, if I ſeem not ſo, in ſuffering you here before me; a fault nothing but a buſinſs of no leſs concern than Life and Death, ſhould a made me guilty of.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: So, there's one lye already.— (aſide)—What buſineſs? The carrying away Sir Thomas's Neice and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wo • d.
sp.p: How the Devil came ſhe to know that?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Come, ſince I know you were ingaged in that pi • ce of Chivalry, you may ſpare the expence of an invenion to hide it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis true Madam; I did give ſome little aſſiſtance in that affair to the ſervice of my friend, but—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: But the extent of your deſire is only to engage my heart i'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis the laſt of all my wiſhes, from the firſt moment I ſaw you at Church—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: At Church?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, at Church Madam;—pray Heav'n ſhe goes to Church (aſide). 'Twas there I firſt beheld you; and there promiſed never to think of any other Women.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: My pretended flekneſs has kept me from Church, ever ſince I've been here; but I believe if he cou'd have thought I had been to be found at Rome, he had ſaid he had ſeen me there;—Well Sir, I will not queſtion the truth of what you ſay: But if I ſhou'd be inclinable to believe you, what wou'd you do to deſerve it?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: All things that's poſſible my Unartful Paſſion will Compell me to.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: All things but Conſtancy; and that I fear is not in your Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It is the only ſin of my Affection, if it be one to love forever.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: O Heaven! that truth dwelt in his words. (aſide)—Swear—Swear that thou loveſt me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I do by all—

sp.speaker: ady
sp.p: Hold,—hold—I know there's nothing but he will Swear: And break it when he has done; and yet he muſt ſwear it;—for there is ſuch a Charm in the Cheat; that again I muſt hear him, and be again deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: How then, I muſt leave you, when next I ſee you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You'll perhaps again be taken from me; let me not part with you now.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then take me with you.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That wee'll talk of by and by.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: But the time will be ſo ſhort.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That we ſhall have no time to talk;—Well hinted I Gad— [Aſide, On then my Dear, that we may not loſe that little we have.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Thomas with Conſtable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A Pox upon you, for a company of uncultivated Clods; where de'e hall me?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Sir, what we do we are bound to; 'tis our Office, therefore pray forgive us

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You are not going to Execution with me, you ask pardon ſo like a Hangman;

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No Sir, Our Warrant is only to carry you before a Juſtice, and from thence I believe to Priſon: but where afterwards I dare not ſay; but I am afraid your Worſhips time is but ſhort.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Not ſo ſhort as you'd make it, you dund-headed Doggs, to be tryed, Condemn'd and Hang'd in a Breath.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No Sir, I hope not; Tho your Worſhip made but quick work with poor Hob.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Aye, aye poor man; his head has done aking by this time:

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'm glad of it; and had I my Sword, and my hands at liberty none of your ſhou'd trouble you long.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O bloody, bloody, away with him; this is bloody Neighbours.
All, Away, away with him.
sp.stage: Enter Friendly and Robin, meeting Probe the Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So Mr. Probe, how de'e find your Patient?

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Alas his Wound is nothing; his Scull is not ſo much as touch't tho he fancies it impoſſible for a cut with a Sword to be leſs than Mortal.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Poor Hob, you muſt ſtill keep him ignorant of his Condition, and make him believe it's dangerous; it may be of uſe to me:

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: I need not do that, his fears won't let him believe otherwiſe; let me ſay what I can.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Robin, come let us go ſee if we can find Mr. Woodvill, for without his help we ſhall hardly bring our Plot to perfection.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not Jove in all his transformations, when he Ungodded himſelf for Mortal Pleaſures, had one hour of Love like me. O for a Night to Revel in; that the Taſte might be turn'd into a Feaſt; And my longing Soul be fill'd with delight.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Is not this Extaſie feigned: And ſhall not the eaſie acceſs you have found to my heart, make me one day ſlighted for another.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Wrong not thy ſelf with ſuch a thought,—there can be no other but thee: Thou Charmer tell me when ſhall I ſee thee again?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I cannot tell, this Evening i'll endeavour it; and if 'tis poſſible I will meet you here;—tell then—Farewell.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Farewell my Dear, Dear Creature.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Have you my things Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: Here they be Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Give 'em to me; i'll put 'em on as I go; if he takes not the neareſt way I may meet him at the lower end of the Walk.
sp.stage: Re-enter Woodvill, meeting Friendly and Robin.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O well met; I find I might have look't long enough for you, had not chance brought me to a ſight of you:—Come Robin the things, quick, qu • ck.

sp.speaker: Robin,
sp.p: Here Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How now, what are theſe for?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nay, prithee ask no queſtions; But if you'll do me a piece of ſervice, come on with this Holy outſide, you muſt ſuffer a Transformation Ned; from a Town Bull to Pariſh-Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's the ſame thing ſtill Frank; But to what end muſt I wear this Mantle, for Iniquity?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Can't you gueſs?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not I faith, unleſs it be to mock Matrimony; And if that's the buſineſs come on, as faſt as you will, I'm for you.

sp.speaker: Frend.
sp.p: How! I did not think thou hadſt been ſo well acquainted with Religion, to be able to act any thing of it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to ſerve a friend upon occaſion Franck; I have ſtudy'd it a little.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And a very little, nor that for any affection thou hadſt to it, i'll be ſworn, Come, come along.
sp.stage: As Woodvill follows, Enter Lady Teſte at the other ſide Mask'd—And pulls him back.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: A word with you Sir,—If the care of ſome departing Soul does not make you too much in haſte.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thou dear Creature, have I met thee here again? And art thou come to perform they laſt promiſe; and let me ſee that beautious Face of thine?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Why ſhou'd you be ſo curious? for if it prove handſome you know the engagement you lye under.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What, to love thee?—'Tis impoſſible my dear for me ever to love any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: So,—What de'e do with this habit then?—I fear there is ſomething to be manag'd in this diſguiſe, not of a piece with your vows.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This habit Child; why I procur'd it a purpoſe to try if by it's aſſiſtance I cou'd find ſome way to get acceſs to thee.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Thou lyeſt thou Devil; and the Curſe of broken promiſes purſue thee for it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hey day! what's the meaning of this Divinity, if you bring me no better fortune, you muſt go home and Cloak for the good Wives of your own Pariſh again.
sp.l: To Levies Tribe they'l part with any thing.

l.hi: And thank the Saint that takes the Offering.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCENE. I.
div.stage: Hob is brought in a Chair by ſome Country Fellows, his Father and Mother with him.

sp.speaker: Old Hob,
sp.p: COme eaſie Neighbours, eaſie, ſet 'en down eaſie.

sp.speaker: Mother,
sp.p: O my poor Child, how doſt thou do?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Worſer and worſer, I find I'm not for this Life.

sp.speaker: Old Hob,
sp.p: Then I hope you'll take warning, how oft have I ſaid. Hob ſays I don't thee concern thy ſelf; what buſineſs is it of thine? Let every Tub ſtand upon its own bottom; but thou thought'ſt becauſe—

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Pray now don't ye talk to me, pray now don't; Don't ye vex me ſo: 'Tis a ſtrange thing you can't let me depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: How de'e Neighbour? how does your Son?

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: Ah Sir, the poor boy I'm afraid will dye.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Who is that Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: It is the Parſon come to Pray with thee Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ha! What do'ſt ſay, the Parſon?—O Lord, I hope it is not come to that is it?—O my heart, O my poor heart will break; O—O Lord.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: Come Patience, Patience Neighbour, have a little Patience—And I hope as you have liv'd a good Chriſtian, you'll take care to dye ſo.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye ſure Sir, that I will, under Mercy; for if I live I will dye a good Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: That's well ſaid, then the firſt thing you muſt do, is to forget and forgive.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Forgive?—What muſt I forgive him that has knock't out my brains? Why then may hap he'll do ſo again.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: If he does, you muſt forgive him.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye,—why then if I muſt, I do forgive him.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Hob, Child here's Mary come to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Mary,
sp.p: How doſt find thy ſelf Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ah Mary, I can't ſpeak to thee.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Poor heart;—do try to ſpeak to her child, for ſhe is thy Wife and no other.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I know I'm ſure to her,—and I do own it before you all, I ask't her the Queſtion, laſt Lammas; and at Allhollows-tide we broke a piece of Money; and if I had liv'd till laſt Sunday, we had been ask'd in the Church.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Ha poor wretch I always thought 'en to pretty to live—Mary, go and kiſs 'en Mary.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I do deſire you all preſent, to take notice of my laſt Will and Teſtimony.—I have forty Shillings in a leatherpurſe under my Beds-head, which I do bequeath unto Mary; And the ball'd-fac'd Heifer that I bought at Tukesbury▪ Fair, I do bequeath unto Mary;—And my new leather Breeches, which I bought againſt Whitſontide: I do bequeath unto Mary; And my Bible, and new Pitchfork, and Tobacco-box, I do bequeath unto Mary: Mary, come and kiſs me once more, Mary you may never kiſs me again.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: How now, what's the matter;—how doſt do Friend?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Dead Sir,—I'm a Dead Man.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: How Dead! Thou art the firſt Dead Man that ever told me ſo; let me feel thy Pulſe.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: O Sir, they do beat, beat, like any Durm.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: O your Pulſe beats very temperate.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Do they Sir?

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Aye, aye, you're better than you was a great deal.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Am I indeed Sir?

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: What have you given him to eat?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Nothing Sir, I have eat no kind of thing: Sir Thomas ſent a Doctor here, and I believe he had a mind tof amiſh me, he gave me a ſort of ſtuffe here made of Barly;—Barly Porridge I think they call it; 'twas no ſooner in but out again; it runs through a man and does no manner of good.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: You muſt have ſome thing to ſtrengthen him; what have you a mind to?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I don't know Sir; I cou'd eat ſomething fit for a man in my Condition;—a little ſomewhat Roaſt;—what de'e think of a little Roaſt-beef now;—and a little Pepper and Vinigar to make it Savory, may hap I cou'd get a bit of that down.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: O a very good thing for a ſick man; let him have it, and give him ſome Sack now and then; there's half a Dozen Bottles within, which Mr. Friendly ſent to comfort him with.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Has a,—God bleſs 'en—▪Ha! he's a good man—Mother give me a little Sack, will ye pray now do.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Well, how de'e find your ſelf now?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ha,—ha—add I don't know Sir,—methinks I'm pretty hoddy now as 'twere.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: That's well, why then let him drink another Cup.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Shall I?—Why ſo, I will then—Mother give me a ſup or two more—Hee—hee—hee.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Ah much good do thy precious heart; how doſt do now Child.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ha—add I'm fine and ſpract now.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Pough,—you'll do very well again; I'd have you try to get up, and i'll come and ſee you again anon.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Thank you Sir, heartily;—Sir, Sir, pray take the Parſon a long with you, I don't care to ſee 'en here, a looks unlucky methinks.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Aye, aye, I will.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Mother I'll try if I can walk a bit.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Do then ſtand up.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Pray lend me my Breeches Father.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: O don't be too bold good Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Give me a little more Sack [Drink]—It's good Sack Mother, pray lend me the—O Lord.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Get on thy Cloths firſt, good Child.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I'm, I'm, very fainty,—I wont venture too ſoon Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Don't then, ſit down, and let them carr thee in again.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Come help Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Sir, Tho.
sp.p: I have misfortunes enough to ſend me into the other world, without a Halter; I need not ſwing thither for a Rogue not worth the Money the Rope will coſt;—but if I be hang'd, it ſhall be a day of mourning for ſome-body.
sp.stage: Enter Wood vill habited like a Parſon.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And you too Sir, have you any thing to ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I hear you are to be try'd for Murder, and as the Fact appears to me, you will ſuffer for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wou'd know in what ſtate, you are in, and if you are prepar'd for Death as you ought to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You know;—What with that Face,—prithee get ſome hair on thy Chin firſt—boy—thy outſide will beget no veneration in me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My inſide won't I'm ſure— [Aſide]—Sir, I expected another ſort of treatment from a man in your Condition.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, what's my Condition Cobble Conſcience?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Do ye know where you are a going?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No nor you neither Sir, for all you get your living by it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This way Sir, won't convey you to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why then I'll go to to'ther place along with you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And is this all the Preparation you intend to make for your Journey.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye Sir, I ſhall go juſt as I am, without Boots or Spurs; you may therefore ſpare your pains, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What an old Reprobat have I to work upon.
sp.stage: Enters Saywell and Friendly. dreſt like a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I'am glad to ſee you in ſuch good Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis the Company Neighbour Saywell, that will bring me to the Gallows;—The Parſon and the Hangman are the two laſt that take leave of us there. Have you brought my Writings.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: I have Sir, and here's a Gentleman recommended to me for an able Lawyer, that will ſettle your Eſtate as you ſhall think fit.

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.p: Sir, here's a young Lady without, deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: O 'tis my Wife, let her come to me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm afraid the help I can give you, will do but little ſervice, for he's as much averſe to a black Gown, as a Non-Con is to a Surplice: What have you done with the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: They're ſafe at my Aunt Friendlies.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Do's Flora know of your Plott.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, nor of her Fathers being here; nor durſt I tell her, till I have effected my deſign; for tho it is only for her ſake, if I do get her Fortune, yet t'wou'd diſpleaſe her if ſhe knew I but attempted it.—Ha!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O, ſhew me, ſhew me, where on my knees I may fix, till my Tears have waſh'd away my Offences; O Sir, forgive my Diſobedience, that has I fear been too much the cauſe of this moſt fatal accident.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hum,—get out of my ſight,—get out of my ſight—Go get you gone to your Rogue, that will have mehang'd, go and I'll provide for ye;—I'll give you a Portion, Twelve-pence and thy Fathers Curſe, be thine Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a Pox is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O do not Curſe me Sir, I have not deſerv'd that, leave me a Beggar if you pleaſe, but with your Bleſſing and I will be contented.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, bleſs thee for contriving to have me hang'd? be gone▪—begone from me quickly, or I will fiſt thee from me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Do any thing Sir, ſo you will heat me;—Let me clear my Innocence, and baniſh me your ſight forever turning to Wood. O Sir, I beſeech you plead for me, it is your Duty to Reconcile us, and yours, and yours turning
[to Mr. Saywell and Friendly]: And every good mans, to help the diſtreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'm ſo amaz'd I cannot think what to do, if I diſcover my ſelf to her in this humour, ſhe'll not have patience to let me undeceive her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, I find our Plot is growing to an end already; How like two Fools we ſhall look by and by, if they find us out in our borrowed ſhapes.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Come, pray let me perſuade you to hear her however, you are never the farther from your Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What can ſhe ſay for her ſelf, am I not brought here for Murder, provok't to it by their invention, ſhe and her Rogue Friendly, that ſhe ran away with; did you not run away with him Huzzey.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very good; Come, I'll reaſon the matter calmly with you; and have you not married him too, againſt my expreſs Command to the Contrary.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, Sir nor never will.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Swear, ſwear that, and damn thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: By all my hopes of future Bleſſings, he is not my Husband; nor till within this half hour, did I know of your impriſonment, or the fatal cauſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: If this be true.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If it be not let miſery p • rſue me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Will you promiſe me not to marry him when I'm dead, for hang me I ſuppoſe they will.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O do not name him, Death wou'd be a thouſand times more wellcome to me, than ſuch a Husband.

sp.speaker: Friend,
sp.p: So now I may go hang my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, on condition that all you have ſaid is true, I do forgive thee, riſe up and Heaven bleſs thee.

sp.speaker: Friendly,
sp.p: Dear Ned, what ſhall I do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, as thou ſaidſt juſt now, hang thy ſelf; for ſince thou canſt not marry to cure thy paſſion, I know no other way.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: You will do well, Sir Thomas, for ſhe has expreſt her ſelf a very dutiful Child.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: She has ſo, and I will reward her for it, here is a Deed of Gift of half my Eſtate, which I did once before deſign for her, but happening to fall in Love at that Juncture, and marrying I alter'd my Reſolution, here Sir,—

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Mr. Nonſuit;

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come and witneſs this, the reſt of my Eſtate I will ſettle upon my Wife, and let the Writings be drawn as ſoon as you can.

sp.speaker: Friendly,
sp.p: Sir, they ſhall be ordered immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sir, your hand too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Withall my heart; and heav • n give a bleſſing to't:

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: There I deliver this as my Act and Deed.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So, I'm glad however I've ſeen this done for her! tho ſhe has renounc't me for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I wiſh I cou'd have liv'd to a ſeen thee married; my death had been more ſupportable to me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wiſh ſo to Sir, for I'm young and know not how the ſubtilties of men may prevail, when you are gone that ſhou'd adviſe me: But for fear this Friendly ſhou'd attempt me again, to make me break the promiſe I have made you; I will this minute put it out of my power, and give my ſelf to this Gentleman Mr. Nonſuit, if he'll pleaſe to accept of me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ha, accept of thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay,—you don't deſerve me, for not letting me know your deſigns upon my Father, am I not fit to be truſted with my own welfare think ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Oons!

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Forgive me Madam, and had I—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay, no Apology, I'm ſatisfi'd that I'm not oblidg'd to your Plot for what I have, but my own.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By all that's ſacred I will deſerve thee, if it be in Love to reward this unexpected bleſſing, tell me you Powers, if there be any that knows a happineſs like mine; how ſhall I expreſs my Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Woons, what is all this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O good Sir, forbear ſwearing; 'tis an hollow'd ſound, and my ears can't bear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Rot you and your ears, you Canonical Pimp, Confuſſion I'm cheated out of my Eſtate too, as well as my life.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No Sir I will take care your Eſtate ſhall be diſpos'd of according to your Act and Deed; and you may live to now if you pleaſe, and enjoy your liberty.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Which you had never wanted (Pardon me Sir) had you given me mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Patience give me Patience.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: In troth, Neighbour,—'tis the beſt Remedy you can have; e'en make uſe of it, and let that ſeem your choice which is not now in your power to help.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do? Wou'd you have me give her to him?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Aye, and your Bleſſing too, or they'll be happy without it; an Eſtate is a good ſtep to it, and that you have given 'em already; and there few Children in this Age, that think their Parents can add any thing more.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come hither,—Take her, and make her—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Any thing but a Wife, or I forbid [Woodvile interpoſes.
the Banes.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Look'ee Frank, while the Jeſt wou'd bare, I was willing to carry it on;—But the Buſineſs grows now too much in earneſt; and the Welfare of my Friend obliges me to make bold with my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What ſay ye, your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye your Lady, and her Companion, were the two Masks that I told you I pick't up, and one of 'em, I thank her, did me the Favour to afford me her Company that Night, if it was Flora ſhe has ſomething very particular in her behaviour that makes her a very agreeable Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou durſt not ſure ſay this to me in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But I dare, Sir, if it be truth, as I'm ſure it is; tho', perhaps, you mayn't care to hear it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By Heav'n thou ly'ſt, and did not her preſence make this place ſacred, thou ſhoud'ſt pay dear for this Blaſphemy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Are you ſo hot? Follow me, and I'll find you a place to allay your fury in.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Follow thee—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Hold, you ſhall not go; What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's the matter?—[As Wood. is going out,
sp.stage: Enter Lady Teſtie in a Mask, meeting him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With your leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What are you ſurpriz'd to ſee me here?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, I'gad, am I, more than ever I was in my Life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis hard to conceal wrongs, from a Jealous Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And 'tis harder for me to do you right, whilſt you conceal your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why did you not meet me, as you promis'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Meet you; S'bud I thought I had you here; but ſince I find I'm maſtaken, pray, Madam, ſatisfie me, who you are? For if you remember, when you and I Bargain'd for a little Familiarity, I was to be under no obligation, till I had ſeen and lik'd you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That you have done already, if you ſpoke truth; but ſince you are ſo apt to forget, refreſh your Memory and look again; What are you Dumb? [Pulls off her Mask.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I ſhou'd be dumb, Madam, if—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If thou hadſt nothing to ſay, but thou haſt a Tongue can never want words to excuſe thy Perjury, ſhou'd I ſtay to hear it; farewel, ungrateful Man.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, very well, what trick next; Fortune is pleaſed to be very merry with me to day, I find I have made a very pretty hand o' this matter;—Loſt both my Miſtreſſes, wrong'd a vertuous Lady, abus'd my Friend, and brought a Quarrel upon me, all in one quarter of an hour,—Hark'ee, Friendly,—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis as thou ſay'ſt, I do lie; and prithee forgive me for it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Sir;—But do you think this will ſatisfie me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: At preſent I hope it will; to Morrow thou ſhalt know more.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: In the mean time then pray make ſome amends to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Wood,
sp.p: I can only ask her pardon, what elſe is requiſite do thou do for me, anon when the Curtains are drawn.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir; you ſhan't be troubl'd with any Night-work of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: That I ſhou'd have both my Eyes, and yet not ſee theſe pair of Counterfeit Knaves; well, 'tis not the firſt time that Whoremongers and Adulters have been cloak't with the Law and the Goſpel.
My Dear, art thou ventur'd hither too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, my Dear, to fetch thee home, hearing Hob was well and abroad, I cou'd no longer bear to have you here, ſince I have recover'd health enough to be happy with you at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho▪
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou?—Health,—and be happy?—What do'ſt thou mean, ha!—Shall I have thee in my Arms? And wil't thou be my Bride to Night?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſhall be what you pleaſe to have me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why then let ſorrow vaniſh, and a Fig for my Daughter, Friendly, take her, and do what thou will't with her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; and to deſerve this Kindneſs; if you get an Heir to Inherit your Eſtate, you ſhall have it again.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hum! Do you jeer an Old Man? Well, if I can't get an Heir, do you, I'm contented now, it ſhou'd be for my Grandſon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How now Ned, engaging afreſh? If you purchaſe there, it muſt be for Life.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my heart;—Madam, ſhall I have Poſſeſſion upon that Condition?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I don't know what may be, after ſeven Years Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He'll be worn out in half that time, Madam, if you don't reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you think it's poſſible, Sir, to reclaim him?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I hope ſo, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So do I, tho' I doubt it; Neice have a care of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Let her take care of her ſelf; her Father left her at my diſpoſal, and if ſhe Marries him, I won't give her a Groat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I ſuppoſe your Courtſhips at an end; for without that Charm, my Beauty, I fear, will have but little force.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Enough, Madam, to make me a Convert, if you dare put me to a Tryal— (Aſide.) —I know not whether Infected by Friendly's Example, or any conceal'd Mischief in this holy Covering, but I find my ſelf of a ſudden ſtrangely enclin'd to do ſomething to repent of, as well as the fooliſh part of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I know ſhe loves him, and if I thought he lov'd her,—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
You need not doubt it, if he Marries her, for nothing but Love can make him do ſuch a Violence to himſelf.
[Aſide to Woodvil.] Ned, purſue your purpoſe, if 'tis honourable for ſuch a Beauty, and eight thouſand Pound,—(if we can work the old fellow to conſent) will be a better Fortune then any thou can'ſt hope for in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If Love goes on as it begins, I ſhall be of thy Opinion Frank.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ask what thou wilt, my Dear, I will deny thee nothing; for thou art every thing to me; What wou • d I give now, that it were Bed time, Neighbour, ha

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Not ſo much as your Lady wou'd give to have it Morning again; for we old Fellows, Sir Thomas, are but troubleſome Companions between a pair of Sheets.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir; you may be miſtaken; what ſay'ſt thou my dear?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hope ſo too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ha! My little Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd I be angry that he cannot love me? I wou'd not love him if I cou'd help it: Shall I then think that a Crime in another, I wou'd my ſelf be guilty of; Alas, 'tis neither of our faults; for fate has decreed me wretched to make him happy, and this way it muſt be done;—Neice to Day I am Sir Thomas, and your Fortune now you ſhall receive from my Gift,—take it, and diſpoſe of it with yourſelf, as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhou'd bluſh ſo to receive it, if I did not hope you wou'd command both it and me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If I do, it ſhall be to beſtow you here;—I know your Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Madam, this generous Act has—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Deſerv'd better uſage than you have treated me with; but I forgive you, and hope I ſhall forget you too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Never, Madam; for tho' I cannot as a Lover, as a Friend I'll hope to deſerve a place in your Memory.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Friend! A cold diſtinction for a heart like mine, unleſs it cou'd degenerate, and be as yours has been to me; however be happy, and if I have contributed any thing to make you ſo, 'twill pleaſe me that I had it in my Power.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: That both theſe young Jades ſhou'd get the better of me!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Aye, and you may thank Heav'n for't, or we had hang'd you; for Hob's Life depended upon your good Behaviour; and had you been ſtill refractory, we had knock't out his Brains and you ſhou'd a Swung for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A very Chriſtian-like Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Twas ſuch as wou'd a ſerv'd our turns, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: There's Maſter Friendly.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: God bleſs you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O, honeſt Hob!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, durſt that Rogue venture hither? Give me my Sword, I'll have a Collop of him I'm reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Will you?—As I hope to be ſav'd—Maſter Friendly—For the Lord ſake do'nt let e'n draw his Sword upon me agen, pray now don't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, no, prithee don't fright thy ſelf;—Good Sir, let me intreat for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Don't ye thirſt after Blood ſo, don't ye;—You have enough of mine to anſwer for already.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What brought him here?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Brought me here?—Why look'ee, Sir, I am through Providence here a going to be Marry'd to Mary; and I don't know how it may pleaſe God to deal with me; therefore I deſire before I go to Church, that I may be at Peace with all the World; forgive me, and I'll forgive you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Poor fellow, he's the firſt I ever knew in his Condition that ſeem'd to have a ſence of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, ſince you will have it ſo, let him give us a Dance, and I will be Friends with him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And the Farm next his Father's, for his Life ſhall be his, if he makes a good Husband;—'Tis in my Gift yet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And ſhall be ever ſo, Madam; and to ſhow I'm pleas'd with your Bounty, I will ſtock it for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O Lord, Scratch, ſtrike up Scratch—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And I'll make one.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay then we'll all joyn.
sp.stage: Enter Country People with a Fidler Playing before 'em.
sp.p: Hey-day! What's here the Country come in upon us?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So much for Dancing, now, my Dear, let's Home; for ſince this proves not a Tenement for Life, I don't care how ſoon I get hence.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And where ſhall we go?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To Church, Madam, and then—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: E'en where you pleaſe;

l.hi: Marriage makes us yours, but remember ſtill
To keep us ſo, Women must have their Will;
For by reſtraining us, you'll only prove
There's no Obedience, where the Tye's not Love.
